known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  Raddin Street
deadends at a stone wall to the east, and returns to the west.  North is a
run-down flophouse, and a large tavern to the south is decorated with a sign
proclaiming it to be the Tipsy Swordmaster.  

[Exits: (north) east south west]
A battered and scarred gladiator guards the entrance to the tavern.

<112hp 151m 23mv> 
e
The Wench's Lute
  This shop lies just off of the east end of Raddin Street, and is exactly
as dingy as one might expect for the surroundings.  One of the windows is
boarded over, and the other is made of bubbled, foggy glass.  An imitation
Harrudim rug covers most of the uneven floor, and a roughly made counter is
toward the east side of the room.  Instruments are mounted on the walls
along with dim lights, providing examples of the shop's wares.  A wooden
doorway leads west.  

[Exits: west]
An unsavory human woman tends the counter.

Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned
with a sword calls attention to the weapon shop to the south.  Raddin street
continues to the east, while the main drag of Sadrent road opens to the
west.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<112hp 151m 19mv> 
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the west, Iron Street leads into
the industrial section of Var Bandor, and to the east, Raddin street winds
through some run-down buildings.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<112hp 151m 18mv> 
w
Iron Street
  Iron street is in a working class part of Var Bandor, and is far from
being one of the nicer areas in the city.  Men walk about along the street
going about their business, and few seem to notice you here.  Some small,
cramped houses line the streets between the larger warehouses, and some
children wearing ragged clothes can be seen playing outdoors.  The people
here do not seem as happy as those in the nicer parts of the city--a faint
air of oppression hangs over the working class folk of Iron Street.  To the
east is Sadrent Road.

<112hp 151m 13mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]

The Armorer

shop.  You can exit back to the west.

<132hp 164m 21mv> 
Before the Gates of the School of Heroes
  Before you stand the gates of the School of Heroes, the renowned center
of training for young adventurers.  It is an enormous structure, composed of
marble, stone, and brick, and has been built upon a rocky hill.  The gates
are forged of wrought iron, and remain open to travelers of every size,
affiliation, and creed.  The central foyer of the School lies ahead, the

here, with a beautiful central fountain and a circle of low bushes.

<190hp 164m 20mv> 
s
The Portal Chamber
  This cubical room is made from blocks of hewn marble.  Benches of similar
stone are set diagonally against the corners of the room, and an open
skylight provides illumination from above.  However, this room is unique in
that it contains four magical gateways which connect the School of Heroes to
various locations in Avendar.  Each glowing with soft blue light, the three
vertical portals are set into the eastern, western, and southern walls.  The
fourth portal is horizontal and circular, and is set into the floor directly
beneath the skylight.  A more mundane doorway leads north, to the courtyard
before the entrance to the School proper.  

[Exits: north east south west down]
(Translucent) A magic mouth hovers in mid-air, grinning nonchalantly.
The magic mouth tells you, 'Are you ready to travel the portals?'
The magic mouth tells you, 'Just say the name of the direction you want to go to learn more.'

<190hp 164m 19mv> 
d
The Entrance to the Tower of Testing
  Just north of the Adventurer's Lounge lies a connecting junction between
it and the Tower of Testing.  This dimly lit vestibule is made of rougher
hewn stone than the smooth bricks of the School proper, giving it a more
ominous air.  A hanging oil lantern which dangles from the ceiling only
enhances this mood, its unsteady light filling the room with trembling
shadows.  Engraved into the stone floor is the iconic sigil of the School of
Heroes, which serves as this chamber's only real ornamentation.  To the
north, the Tower awaits, the many sounds of its beasts echoing off of the
ancient stone walls.

A standing sign offers information to students.

[Exits: north south]

<190hp 164m 18mv> 
n
n
The Beginning of the First Floor
  The Tower of Testing's first floor is a simple and rugged affair, built
of heavy, rough-hewn bricks.  Torches line the grey walls, and a chill
moisture clings to the air.  The floor underfoot is well-trod and packed
with rough mortar.  The first level of the Tower opens up into a low-lit,
open, and shadowy chamber.  There are no windows, and the dank air suggests
that this part is still below ground level.  The chamber continues to the
north, where the screeches of rats and the crackles of torches fill the
quiet air.  

A sign is affixed to an iron stand.

A Breezy Stairwell
  This stairwell is in the far northeast, just outside of the first floor
proper.  It is rugged and dark, lit with flickering torches.  However, as
the stairs climb higher, the chill cling of the air lessens and the basement
scent dims.  Warmer, fresher air travels downward on a faint breeze, causing
the flames to dance wildly atop their torches.  The steps are worn and
smooth, suggesting the passage of many feet.  To the south lies the
rat-infested first floor of the Tower of Testing, while the second floor
awaits above.

A Glass Stairwell
  The second floor comes to an end with a stairwell leading upward.  The
tower here begins a transition away from the rough-hewn stone of the lower
levels toward white brick and tile, much like that of the School of Heroes. 
The ceilings are substantially higher than the floor below, with high glass
panels that follow the stairs as they proceed further up.  From here you
have a pleasant but commanding view of Avendar's distant horizons, with
vents letting in further fresh air from above.  The stairway is
significantly warmer than below.

The Beginning of the Third Floor
  The third floor of the Tower of Testing is a stone and tile affair, much
like the School of Heroes.  The bricks are white and lit by lanterns which
hang from the ceiling, as well as the large glass windows which look out
into the surrounding skyscape.  The tiles are dark and well-trod, showing

blood mar the floor, ceiling and walls, with the high screech of imps never
far from the ear.  To the south, a glass-enclosed stairwell descends to the
second floor, while the current one continues to the north.

The Beginning of the Third Floor
  The third floor of the Tower of Testing is a stone and tile affair, much
like the School of Heroes.  The bricks are white and lit by lanterns which
hang from the ceiling, as well as the large glass windows which look out
into the surrounding skyscape.  The tiles are dark and well-trod, showing

clear and fresh due to better ventilation; however, it still stings the nose
with the acrid scent of summoning.  Scratches and the spattering of dark
blood mar the floor, ceiling and walls, with the high screech of imps never
far from the ear.  To the south, a glass-enclosed stairwell descends to the
second floor, while the current one continues to the north.

The East Side of the Third Floor
  The third floor of the Tower of Testing is a stone and tile affair, much
like the School of Heroes.  The bricks are white and lit by lanterns which
hang from the ceiling, as well as the large glass windows which look out
into the surrounding skyscape.  The tiles are dark and well-trod, showing
the scuffs of many young adventurers.  The air on this floor is surprisingly
clear and fresh due to better ventilation; however, it still stings the nose
with the acrid scent of summoning.  Scratches and the spattering of dark
blood mar the floor, ceiling and walls save the uncharacteristic cleanliness
of the western one.  The hall continues north and south.

<143hp 164m 43mv> 
help experience
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Experience                                                       |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/


Your character advances in power by gaining experience. The amount of 
experience you need to advance a level will increase as your level 
increases.
  
You gain experience by: 
     * Being part of a group that kills a monster 
     * Gaining mastery of a skill 
     * Completing certain quests or tasks 
     * Exploring new places
  
You lose experience if: 
     * You and the mobile you kill are both good-aligned 
  
The experience you get from a kill depends on several things: 
     * How many players are in your group, and their levels
     * Your level versus the level of the creature 
     * Your alignment versus the creature's alignment 
     * Some random variation.

Additionally, there are some creatures of great power which will take you 
much longer to kill than regular foes. If you are successful in slaying 
such foes, you may find that you learn substantially more experience than 
is normal.

Working in a group may be the most effective way of gaining experience.
However, the amount of experience you earn will decrease for each person
in your group after the first three; thus, the optimum group size for
earning experience is three, though groups both larger and smaller have
been known to be effective as well. Note that charmed mobiles in your
group do not count against the group total for purposes for experience.
  
While anyone may group with anyone else who is willing, experience will
be doled out according to group contribution. For example, a level 10 who
is grouped with a level 50 will receive significantly less experience for
the same kill than if he were grouped with a level 20 instead. On the
other hand, the level 50 could help him kill much larger prey, and thus
may (or may not) ultimately prove a more useful groupmate.
  
See also: ADVANCEMENT, GROUPING

<129hp 164m 43mv> 
help auto
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Automatic Action and Display Settings                            |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Syntax: autolist or settings

Avendar uses various automatic action settings, to ease the boredom of
always splitting gold and sacrificing corpses, There are also several
display settings that one may choose from. The commands are as follows:

Command      : Purpose
=======        =======

AUTOMATIC TOGGLES

autoassist   : makes you automatically join your group in melee
autoattack   : toggles melee attacks
autodate     : show new dates as in-game day changes
autodefend   : toggles melee defenses
autodestroy  : destroy corpses on kill (if autoloot is on, only empty corpses)
autoexit     : display room exits upon entering a room
autogold     : take all money from dead mobiles
autoloot     : take all items from dead mobiles
autooath     : toggles whether you accept oaths of fealty
autosplit    : split up gold from combat among your group members
autotips     : toggles the tips feed
accept       : toggles whether you accept items others 'give' to you
nofollow     : toggles between accepting/not accepting followers
noyell       : prevents involuntarily yells when being attacked
nosummon     : toggles whether you can be summoned by those out your PK range
autopeek     : attempt to peek at people's inventories
autotracks   : attempt to cover your tracks
autoreverse  : Cease attempting to counter-disarm foes.

DISPLAY CONFIGURATION

prompt       : toggles your prompt on/off
color/colour : toggles ANSI colour
excolor      : toggles extra colors
epshow       : toggles display of exploration points earned
translate    : shows translated text of your communication
showlines    : toggles line numbers in the editor
combine      : toggle combining items
compact      : toggles extra line-spacing
brief        : toggles showing room descriptions (no EP gained when on)
scroll       : sets page buffer size (default 24 lines)


See also: EP, SCROLL, PROMPT, TRANSLATE, OATH, BRIEF, TIPS

  The third floor of the Tower of Testing is a stone and tile affair, much

<134hp 164m 60mv> A Marble Stairwell
  A marble stairwell leads upward to the fourth floor of the Tower of
Testing.  The white stones of the third level end at the entrance to this
stairwell, instead replaced by the iconic marble of the School's main level.
The tile floor looks less worn and of a higher sheen, and the stairwell
itself is polished to a high gloss.  Arched windows look out onto the world
at large, high enough to give the faint of heart a bit of pause.  The sounds
of battle ring out from the floor above.  The long hall of the third floor
lies to the north.

u
A Marble Stairwell
  A marble stairwell ends at the doorstep of the fourth floor of the Tower
of Testing.  This entire floor is done in the polished black tile of the
School of Heroes proper, and the walls are a high, glossy marble.  The
chamber which composes the fourth floor is the largest and most open yet,
the great expanse of its floor composing a patterned relief of the School's
iconic sigil.  The air is cool but smelling of exertion, blood, and metal. 
Lanterns hang from the ceiling to illuminate the final steps before entering
the floor.  Down the stairs, the third floor awaits.  

A plaque is inset into the wall at the top of the stairs.

<141hp 151m 78mv> 
help dual wield
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Dual Wield (Skill)                                               |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  0.0 rounds
Activation cost :  0 mana

Dual wielding is the ability to use an additional weapon in the character's
offhand. Weapons being dual wielded will suffer a slight penalty in the amount
of damage and have a lesser chance of iterative attacks. Weapon weight must be
considered with this skill, as only weapons lighter then the one being wielded
in the main hand are capable of being dual wielded. Swordmasters are exempt
from this restriction, and can dual wield nearly any two swords they can hold.
Certain unwieldy combinations of weapons will be more awkward to defend
oneself with.

Large-sized races, such as the chaja or alatharya, are able to hold certain
kinds of two-handed weapons with one hand, and dual wield them. The balance of
spears, staves, and polearms are such that this is not possible for these
weapons.

The ambidextrous trait, available upon creation and given to gladiators and
swordmasters automatically, reduces but does not remove the weight
restrictions (though swordmasters have none in either case).


See also: PARRY, AMBIDEXTROUS

<220hp 164m 176mv> 
help ambidextrous
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Ambidextrous                                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Cost: 2 trains

This trait represents a character's natural ambidexterity, which manifests
itself in being able to dual wield heavier weapons.  In practice, this means
the off hand weapon can be closer to the main hand weapon's weight than would
otherwise be possible.

Swordmasters and gladiators automatically receive this trait upon creation,
though it is merely a formality for swordmasters; they may dual wield any two
swords regardless of weight.

See also: DUAL WIELD

The Roof of the Tower of Testing
  The high roof of the Tower is shielded by a barely perceptible field of

A Small Delivery Office
  This small office is walled with the same white-stone blocks as are used
in the Hall of Arms and lined with similar iron sconces.  It is decorated
with hanging burgundy tapestries, giving it a richer, more mercantile feel. 
A small wooden desk and chair sit against the western wall, bearing a tiny
inkwell and quill-stand.  The ceiling is low and plain, the light from the
sconces playing across its uneven surface.  Open doorways lead out of the
office to the north and south, with the northern portal shimmering with
magical energy.

n
Before the Gates of the School of Heroes
  Before you stand the gates of the School of Heroes, the renowned center
of training for young adventurers.  It is an enormous structure, composed of
marble, stone, and brick, and has been built upon a rocky hill.  The gates
are forged of wrought iron, and remain open to travelers of every size,
affiliation, and creed.  The central foyer of the School lies ahead, the
marble edifice looming over its well-worn gates.  A small courtyard opens
here, with a beautiful central fountain and a circle of low bushes.  

[Exits: north south]
     A beautiful golden fountain gushes water.

<282hp 166m 216mv> 
s
The Portal Chamber
  This cubical room is made from blocks of hewn marble.  Benches of similar
stone are set diagonally against the corners of the room, and an open
skylight provides illumination from above.  However, this room is unique in
that it contains four magical gateways which connect the School of Heroes to
various locations in Avendar.  Each glowing with soft blue light, the three
vertical portals are set into the eastern, western, and southern walls.  The
fourth portal is horizontal and circular, and is set into the floor directly
beneath the skylight.  A more mundane doorway leads north, to the courtyard
before the entrance to the School proper.  

[Exits: north east south west down]
(Translucent) A magic mouth hovers in mid-air, grinning nonchalantly.
The magic mouth tells you, 'Are you ready to travel the portals?'
The magic mouth tells you, 'Just say the name of the direction you want to go to learn more.'

<282hp 166m 215mv> 
d
The Entrance to the Tower of Testing
  Just north of the Adventurer's Lounge lies a connecting junction between
it and the Tower of Testing.  This dimly lit vestibule is made of rougher
hewn stone than the smooth bricks of the School proper, giving it a more
ominous air.  A hanging oil lantern which dangles from the ceiling only
enhances this mood, its unsteady light filling the room with trembling
shadows.  Engraved into the stone floor is the iconic sigil of the School of
Heroes, which serves as this chamber's only real ornamentation.  To the
north, the Tower awaits, the many sounds of its beasts echoing off of the
ancient stone walls.

A standing sign offers information to students.

[Exits: north south]

<282hp 166m 214mv>

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  This corner of the lounge is a place for friends
to gather before entering the Tower of Testing, which trains young
adventurers in the ways of battle.  The dim echoes of its sounds filter back
into the lounge now and then, as a solemn reminder of how all students
eventually make their fortunes.  To the west and south, the lounge
continues.  Far to the west is the Hall of Trials and its training
exercises.  

An sign hangs upon the eastern wall.

[Exits: north south west]
A shuddeni student taps on one of her teeth, her expression contemplative.

The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  This corner of the lounge includes a small,
burbling fountain to fill flasks or bottles before moving on to the School's
challenges.  The walls are made of older, darker stones than the floor
above, but are well-lit and smoothly cut.  A hallway leads to the west,
leading to the Chamber of the Voice and the Hall of Trials.  The lounge
itself continues to the south and east.  

A prominent bulletin board hangs from the northern wall.

The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  It is filled with chairs, couches, and other
furniture, allowing students of the School to gather, converse, or join
together.  The walls are made older, darker stones than the floor above, but
are lit by similar iron sconces.  The floor is hardwood, rather than tile,
to dampen the clatter of steps.  The lounge continues to the north and east,
while the foyer of the School of Heroes is up a flight of marble stairs.  A
chamber lies to the south, home to the School's mascot.  

A sign stands near the stairwell.

A Rough-Hewn Stairwell
  To the west of the Adventurer's Lounge is a western alcove.  A set of
well-trodden stairs descend to a lower level and the beginning of the Hall of
Trials.  The alcove and the stairs it contains, much like other parts of the
School's lower facilities, are made of old, rough-hewn stone.  A hanging
banner informs students of where the stairs lead, and provides a splash of
color to an otherwise dark and grey passage.  Footsteps echo here, and the
cool air carries with it the musty scent of an ancient basement.  To the
east lies the inviting warmth of the lounge, while below await the School's
trials of the mind.  

[Exits: east down]

<282hp 166m 209mv> 
d
You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Entrance to the Hall of Trials
  The entrance to the Hall of Trials is a gloomy affair, made from heavy
blocks of rough-hewn stone.  An old, echoing stairwell leads down to this
somber room, its wide steps worn with the passing of many ages.  Much like
the Tower of Testing, the Hall of Trials is lit with lonely oil lanterns,
casting the old stone with many shadows.  The air is cool and musty,
bringing with it the scents of old water and rich earth.  Through an archway
to the north lies the Hall proper, which contains many exercises to test new
students to the School of Heroes.  The stairwell leads upward into a small
alcove which leads back into the Adventurer's Lounge.  

A prominent sign is mounted to the wall at the bottom of the stairs.  

[Exits: north up]

<282hp 166m 208mv> 
n
You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Hall of Trials
  The Hall of Trials is intended to help students of the School of Heroes
to learn how to overcome basic obstacles and use universal techniques.  This
includes physical barriers, environmental conditions, and abilities
available to all adventurers.  The Hall is incredibly old, built of
rough-hewn blocks that have the musty scent of age.  The floor has been worn
smooth by generations of young adventurers walking upon it, but is generally
swept clean of debris.  At regular intervals along the ceiling are oil
lanterns, which cast shadows throughout.  To the west, a doorway leads to an
adjoining hallway.  

A plaque near the door reads, "The Test of Keys".

The Test of the Statue
  The room which houses the Test of the Statue is almost perfectly cubical,
walled with a series of rough-hewn blocks.  Unlike much of the Hall of
Trials, this room seems less ancient and more heavily trafficked.  Fully ten
feet on a side, the only notable feature of the room is a freestanding
pedestal at the room's center.  Atop the pedestal is a stone statue, carved
in the likeness of a stone gargoyle.  A lantern hanging from the ceiling
casts the room with fickle light.  The Hall of Trials lies to the west.

<302hp 172m 215mv> 
l caladaran
An academic of mild statue, Jeskach is a lean, middle-aged caladaran with
skin like birch bark.  His hair is a wild, bushy tangle akin to unruly
shrubbery; it provides a comical offset to the seriousness of his
expression.  A dedicant of Chadraln, he spent much of his youth studying the
known world within the Earendam Library.  His focus shifted when he was
hired by the enigmatic owner of the School of Heroes, instead spending his
days imparting some of his knowledge.  Now he administers the Test of the
Statue, and indulges his love of reading when not otherwise occupied.  
Jeskach is in excellent condition.

Jeskach is using:
<worn about body> pale grey robes of the Chadralnite Order
<two-handed>      a simple pine staff

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Test of Keys
  The side corridor runs east and west, sloping downward as it proceeds
from the Hall of Trials.  The walls are cut from rough-hewn stone, and the
passing of endless years has left them uneven.  Tiny patches of moss cling
to the rock, and a slow drip of water makes the close air damp as well as
musty.  Hanging lamps light the corridor, although they flicker off and on,
making the light seem less steady than the floors above.  To the east, the
passage returns to the School proper, while to the west, it is interrupted
by at a wooden door.

<310hp 172m 208mv> The Hall of Trials
  The Hall of Trials is intended to help students of the School of Heroes
to learn how to overcome basic obstacles and use universal techniques.  This
includes physical barriers, environmental conditions, and abilities
available to all adventurers.  The Hall is incredibly old, built of
rough-hewn blocks that have the musty scent of age.  The floor has been worn
smooth by generations of young adventurers walking upon it, but is generally
swept clean of debris.  At regular intervals along the ceiling are oil
lanterns, which cast shadows throughout.  To the west, a doorway leads to an
adjoining hallway.  

A plaque near the door reads, "The Test of Keys".

[Exits: north south west]

<310hp 172m 207mv> 
s
The Entrance to the Hall of Trials
  The entrance to the Hall of Trials is a gloomy affair, made from heavy
blocks of rough-hewn stone.  An old, echoing stairwell leads down to this
somber room, its wide steps worn with the passing of many ages.  Much like
the Tower of Testing, the Hall of Trials is lit with lonely oil lanterns,
casting the old stone with many shadows.  The air is cool and musty,
bringing with it the scents of old water and rich earth.  Through an archway
to the north lies the Hall proper, which contains many exercises to test new
students to the School of Heroes.  The stairwell leads upward into a small
alcove which leads back into the Adventurer's Lounge.  

A prominent sign is mounted to the wall at the bottom of the stairs.

A Rough-Hewn Stairwell
  To the west of the Adventurer's Lounge is a western alcove.  A set of
well-trodden stairs descend to a lower level and the beginning of the Hall of
Trials.  The alcove and the stairs it contains, much like other parts of the
School's lower facilities, are made of old, rough-hewn stone.  A hanging
banner informs students of where the stairs lead, and provides a splash of
color to an otherwise dark and grey passage.  Footsteps echo here, and the
cool air carries with it the musty scent of an ancient basement.  To the
east lies the inviting warmth of the lounge, while below await the School's
trials of the mind.

<310hp 172m 203mv> 
e
The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  This corner of the lounge includes a small,
burbling fountain to fill flasks or bottles before moving on to the School's
challenges.  The walls are made of older, darker stones than the floor
above, but are well-lit and smoothly cut.  A hallway leads to the west,
leading to the Chamber of the Voice and the Hall of Trials.  The lounge
itself continues to the south and east.  

A prominent bulletin board hangs from the northern wall.

<310hp 172m 202mv> 
The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  It is filled with chairs, couches, and other
furniture, allowing students of the School to gather, converse, or join
together.  The walls are made older, darker stones than the floor above, but
are lit by similar iron sconces.  The floor is hardwood, rather than tile,
to dampen the clatter of steps.  The lounge continues to the north and east,
while the foyer of the School of Heroes is up a flight of marble stairs.  A
chamber lies to the south, home to the School's mascot.  

A sign stands near the stairwell.

The Chamber of the Voice
  This small room is not far from the marble stairs which descend into the
Adventurer's Lounge.  Called the Chamber of the Voice, it houses one of the
School's most distinguished magical entities: the magic mouth.  Although its
origin is the subject of many rumors, it is both animate and aware.  It
chose this space for itself not long after the initial renovation of the
lounge, so it could be in close proximity to the School's center of
conversation.  The room itself is a simple affair, with matching hardwood
paneling and flooring.  Two potted plants sit near the rear of the room, one
in each corner, with a globe of light at the ceiling's center.  The
Adventurer's Lounge awaits to the north.  

A silver plaque is set into the wall, glittering enticingly.

The Entrance to the Hall of Victors
  This spur off of the Adventurer's Lounge leads to a tremendous archway. 
It is particularly ancient, even for the School, and is marked by
now-unreadable druidic markings.  Whatever the original use for this
still-standing arch, the long-forgotten laborers who built the School used
it as a transition into another underground Hall.  Named the Hall of
Victors, it is designed to reward those who complete the School's many
trials.  The wooden floor of the west gives way to a rough-hewn stone not
altogether unlike the Tower of Testing, creating a regal but imposing
effect.  Two mounted globes of light illuminate the archway.  The Hall's
interior lies east, while the lounge is to the west.  

A small note is tacked to the archway.

The Hall of Victors
  The Hall of Victors houses the emissary of the family of the School of
Heroes' illustrious founder, and it is his task to reward those valiant
young adventurers who complete the Tower of Testing.  The rough-hewn stone
of the arched entryway gives way to a set of two large steps, and then a
large, circular platform made of polished tiles.  The walls transition
almost immediately into the School's characteristic marble.  The entrance to
the Hall of Victors lies to the west, while an opulent chamber lies to the
south in its interior.  

A huge statue stands at the center of the platform, depicting a stylized man
and woman.

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
An Exotic Parlor in the Hall of Victors
  A great octagonal room, this sumptuous parlor opens up to a fantastically
high ceiling.  Many thick, blood-red drapes shroud the marblework of its
walls, giving it a great tent-like atmosphere.  Just above the sturdy bronze
rodding that holds the drapery aloft, the ceiling slopes upward into a
sharp, open-topped steeple.  A number of polished, dull orbs of light line
the interior of the steeple's high point, the bronze chains that dangle
beneath them glittering like tiny stars.  Against the south wall, a massive
and ornate divan dominates the room, its elaborate designs only heightening
the general exoticism.  Much of the floor is covered by a circular farsh
rug, covering the polished Harrudim tile beneath it.  The scents of spice
hang in the dim, smoky air, giving the parlor an even more opulent flair.

l man
An imposing, dark-skinned man with piercing eyes, Zebenar Kinest is the
most recent owner of the School of Heroes.  His coal-black hair is
well-groomed, matching both his opulent surroundings and the fine cut of his
clothing.  Once a famed scourge of young adventurers throughout Avendar, he
eventually realized there were safer ways to indulge in his amusements. 
Using the fortunes he had amassed through his famous exploits, he purchased
the School of Heroes for its disconcerting record of imp-related training
accidents.  He now rewards those who survive the Tower of Testing with a
small token of his esteem.  
Zebenar Kinest is in excellent condition.

Directions to Discount Guides of Var Bandor
===========================================
1. From the golden fountain, head south to the Chamber of Travel.
2. The portal to the east will take you to Var Bandor.
3. From the temple, head south once.
4. Head east until you see the fountain in Center Square.
5. Go north on Sadrent Road.  Go east at the first four-way
   intersection, onto Raddin Street.
6. Go east two rooms, and then go north into the shop.
7. Hire a guide from Arannia to take you to Jasa Lake.

<310hp 172m 216mv> 
l statue
This massive statue is divided into two halves.  The first, made entirely
of meteoric iron, represents a heavily muscled man.  In his eyes burn the
flames of war, and a massive hammer rests in his tremendous hands.  He is
armored in plate mail, save a helmet, leaving his head fully visible.  

The other half is a silvery, feminine figure.  She is heavily stylized,
bearing two separate faces.  One possesses two diamond eyes and a soothing
smile; the other has eyes of inset ruby and a fierce, grinning mouth.  Her
body is lithe and robed in draping, silken cloth.  

The two forms are fused at the back to one another, never to face each
other.  His clutched fist and her outstretched hand beckon to all who see
them.

The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  This corner of the lounge is a place for friends
to gather before entering the Tower of Testing, which trains young
adventurers in the ways of battle.  The dim echoes of its sounds filter back
into the lounge now and then, as a solemn reminder of how all students
eventually make their fortunes.  To the west and south, the lounge
continues.  Far to the west is the Hall of Trials and its training
exercises.

<310hp 172m 211mv> 
n
The Entrance to the Tower of Testing
  Just north of the Adventurer's Lounge lies a connecting junction between
it and the Tower of Testing.  This dimly lit vestibule is made of rougher
hewn stone than the smooth bricks of the School proper, giving it a more
ominous air.  A hanging oil lantern which dangles from the ceiling only
enhances this mood, its unsteady light filling the room with trembling
shadows.  Engraved into the stone floor is the iconic sigil of the School of
Heroes, which serves as this chamber's only real ornamentation.  To the
north, the Tower awaits, the many sounds of its beasts echoing off of the
ancient stone walls.

A standing sign offers information to students.

[Exits: north south]

<310hp 172m 210mv> 
n
The Beginning of the First Floor
  The Tower of Testing's first floor is a simple and rugged affair, built
of heavy, rough-hewn bricks.  Torches line the grey walls, and a chill
moisture clings to the air.  The floor underfoot is well-trod and packed
with rough mortar.  The first level of the Tower opens up into a low-lit,
open, and shadowy chamber.  There are no windows, and the dank air suggests
that this part is still below ground level.  The chamber continues to the
north, where the screeches of rats and the crackles of torches fill the
quiet air.  

A sign is affixed to an iron stand.

to gather before entering the Tower of Testing, which trains young
adventurers in the ways of battle.  The dim echoes of its sounds filter back
into the lounge now and then, as a solemn reminder of how all students
eventually make their fortunes.  To the west and south, the lounge
continues.  Far to the west is the Hall of Trials and its training
exercises.  

An sign hangs upon the eastern wall.

The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  This corner of the lounge includes a small,

challenges.  The walls are made of older, darker stones than the floor
above, but are well-lit and smoothly cut.  A hallway leads to the west,

A Rough-Hewn Stairwell
  To the west of the Adventurer's Lounge is a western alcove.  A set of

The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  It is filled with chairs, couches, and other
furniture, allowing students of the School to gather, converse, or join
together.  The walls are made older, darker stones than the floor above, but
are lit by similar iron sconces.  The floor is hardwood, rather than tile,
to dampen the clatter of steps.  The lounge continues to the north and east,
while the foyer of the School of Heroes is up a flight of marble stairs.  A
chamber lies to the south, home to the School's mascot.

<310hp 172m 211mv> 
The Chamber of the Voice
  This small room is not far from the marble stairs which descend into the
Adventurer's Lounge.  Called the Chamber of the Voice, it houses one of the
School's most distinguished magical entities: the magic mouth.  Although its
origin is the subject of many rumors, it is both animate and aware.  It
chose this space for itself not long after the initial renovation of the
lounge, so it could be in close proximity to the School's center of
conversation.  The room itself is a simple affair, with matching hardwood
paneling and flooring.  Two potted plants sit near the rear of the room, one
in each corner, with a globe of light at the ceiling's center.  The
Adventurer's Lounge awaits to the north.  

A silver plaque is set into the wall, glittering enticingly.

<310hp 172m 209mv> 
u
The Foyer of the School of Heroes
  The School of Heroes begins with a grand foyer, complete with a vaulted
ceiling held aloft by great marble columns.  The room is spacious and airy,
with high, white marble walls and mounted, shining globes to provide light. 
Two great marble stairways sit back, just off center toward the room's north
side.  One ascends to an upper level of the School, and spirals about a
great glass pillar as it rises.  A well-made desk sits not far from the
foyer's entrance, giving the receptionist an opportunity to greet new
students.  The other descends to a lower level, and voices echo from its
depths.  Three halls open to the north, east, and west, leading to other
branches of the School.  The corridor to the south leads to the School's
iron gates.  

A large sign sits off to one side, offering directions to students.

grounds.'

now.'

The Beginning of the Hall of Professions
  The Hall of Professions is the part of the School of Heroes dedicated to
the training of adventurers in their respective guilds.  Since many of the
skills taught here are rudimentary, many of Avendar's individual guilds are
not represented; instead, a broader professional trainer serves each
respective classification.  The floor and walls are made from granite,
giving the hallway itself a cool, clean feel.  To the east is a fighting pit
where young warriors train, while to the west, a well-supplied classroom
lends itself to the instruction of rudimentary scholars.  The Hall of
Professions continues to the north, while the School's foyer is to the
south.

The Fighting Pit
  Three steps descend from the hallway into this chamber, which serves as a
training area for aspiring young warriors.  The floor is padded, marked with
spots of blood and sweat from those who have practiced here in the past.  A
myriad of weapons line the walls, representing all of the martial creeds of
Avendar's battle guilds.  The room is lit by simple iron-mounted lights,
bright enough to ease instruction and demonstration.  The air here is heavy
with the scents of exertion, stinging the noses of those who enter it.  To
the west lies the Hall of Professions.

The Training Room
  This large room is divided into two major sections: the first is a
fighting area, while the second is a series of tables and a chalk board. 
The combat area is lined with a myriad of common weapons, and covers the
basic instruction of fighting technique.  The chalk board and tables cover
the rudiments of arcane magic; the board outlines basic defensive spells and
the methods of weapon branding and conjuration.  The various tables give
students a place, if they wish it, to sit and read about their early powers
and methods.  There is no desk for the instructor, but rather much open
space for them to move back and forth between study and practical
instruction.

The End of the Hall of Professions
  The Hall of Professions come to an end here, with the last of its
trainers.  This wing of the School of Heroes is dedicated to training in
basic skills and themes, so young adventurers know what to expect from their
future.  Broad, professional trainers serve the School in this function,
offering information and help to students of various guilds.  To the east, a
wild grove grows of its own accord to assist young naturalists.  To the
west, a small sanctuary serves young mentalists in their future endeavors. 
To the south, the Hall of Professions continues.

A Wild Grove
  A small but curious grove grows within the School of Heroes, complete
with perception-defying trees and small animals.  The chamber itself has
given way to a great canopy above, which serves as a makeshift ceiling.  The
great shadow of the limbs above gives the room a dank, earthy feel, with
luminescent moss bathing the area in a blue glow.  The clatter of animals
and birds within the branches very much makes this place feel like a
fragment of the deepest wild.  A doorway to the west leads back into the
civilized world of the Hall of Professions.  

A single white-plumed arrow stands upright in the rich earth.

The Entrance to the Hall of Arms
  The Hall of Arms is named so because it is intended to introduce all
young adventurers to the tools of their trade: weapons and armor.  The
entrance to the Hall is patterned differently than the foyer to the west;
instead of marble columns, it has gilded plating which covers the ceiling
above.  The floor is patterned with polished tile, although instead of
depicting the sigil of the School itself, it is a stylized sword and shield.
The scent of heated copper and smoke is dimly present in the room,
suggesting a forge within a reasonable proximity.  The Hall branches out to
the north, east, and south.  

A tall sign directs students to the services within the Hall of Arms.  

[Exits: north east south west]

The Hero's Armory
  This branch of the Hall of Arms includes the same pale stone and gilded
ceiling as its northern counterpart.  The room itself uses furniture
sparingly, offering a bench along the western wall for students to sit.  A
counter lines the south wall, made of polished wood.  The walls and the
front of the counter are decorated with various examples of the School's
in-house wares, including copper mail, shields, and cloth or hide
stitchwork.  The armory is well-lit and well-maintained on all accounts.  To
the east lies another shop, while the entrance to the Hall of Arms lies to
the north.  

A sign sits upon the counter with additional instructions.

The Traveler's Purse
  The pale stones of the Hall of Arms give way to a far more lavish room,
complete with marble columns and polished marble walls.  Dark, clean-swept
tiles line the floor, broken up by couches and tall, potted plants.  The
east wall is arrayed with teller stations protected by heavy, magically
reinforced bars.  Known for its ties to the Bank of Var Bandor and the famed
Dantaron Vault in Earendam, the Traveler's Purse has a sterling reputation
and shares account access with its partners.  Standing lights plated in
precious metals illuminate the Purse, giving it an even richer feel than it
already had.  The Hall of Arms awaits to the west.  

A gilded sign stands near the teller windows.  

[Exits: west]

<310hp 172m 198mv> 
The Entrance to the Hall of Arms
  The Hall of Arms is named so because it is intended to introduce all
young adventurers to the tools of their trade: weapons and armor.  The
entrance to the Hall is patterned differently than the foyer to the west;
instead of marble columns, it has gilded plating which covers the ceiling
above.  The floor is patterned with polished tile, although instead of
depicting the sigil of the School itself, it is a stylized sword and shield.
The scent of heated copper and smoke is dimly present in the room,
suggesting a forge within a reasonable proximity.  The Hall branches out to
the north, east, and south.  

A tall sign directs students to the services within the Hall of Arms.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<310hp 172m 197mv> 
s
The Hero's Armory
  This branch of the Hall of Arms includes the same pale stone and gilded
ceiling as its northern counterpart.  The room itself uses furniture
sparingly, offering a bench along the western wall for students to sit.  A
counter lines the south wall, made of polished wood.  The walls and the
front of the counter are decorated with various examples of the School's
in-house wares, including copper mail, shields, and cloth or hide
stitchwork.  The armory is well-lit and well-maintained on all accounts.  To
the east lies another shop, while the entrance to the Hall of Arms lies to
the north.  

A sign sits upon the counter with additional instructions.

<310hp 172m 195mv> 
The Foyer of the School of Heroes
  The School of Heroes begins with a grand foyer, complete with a vaulted
ceiling held aloft by great marble columns.  The room is spacious and airy,
with high, white marble walls and mounted, shining globes to provide light. 
Two great marble stairways sit back, just off center toward the room's north
side.  One ascends to an upper level of the School, and spirals about a
great glass pillar as it rises.  A well-made desk sits not far from the
foyer's entrance, giving the receptionist an opportunity to greet new
students.  The other descends to a lower level, and voices echo from its
depths.  Three halls open to the north, east, and west, leading to other
branches of the School.  The corridor to the south leads to the School's
iron gates.  

A large sign sits off to one side, offering directions to students.

[Exits: north east south west up down]
A mossy-haired caladaran woman sits at the reception desk.

Inside the Gates
  Past the wrought iron gates is a wide corridor with walls cut from solid
granite blocks, lit by mounted white globes.  The entry corridor is
surprisingly simple for such a vast and well-known establishment, as it
bears no notable ornamentation.  The School's foyer awaits to the north,
opening up from the corridor's enclosure into a vast chamber.  To the south
lies the School's entrance.

Before the Gates of the School of Heroes
  Before you stand the gates of the School of Heroes, the renowned center
of training for young adventurers.  It is an enormous structure, composed of
marble, stone, and brick, and has been built upon a rocky hill.  The gates
are forged of wrought iron, and remain open to travelers of every size,
affiliation, and creed.  The central foyer of the School lies ahead, the
marble edifice looming over its well-worn gates.  A small courtyard opens

<310hp 172m 210mv>

The Portal Chamber
  This cubical room is made from blocks of hewn marble.  Benches of similar
stone are set diagonally against the corners of the room, and an open
skylight provides illumination from above.  However, this room is unique in
that it contains four magical gateways which connect the School of Heroes to
various locations in Avendar.  Each glowing with soft blue light, the three
vertical portals are set into the eastern, western, and southern walls.  The
fourth portal is horizontal and circular, and is set into the floor directly
beneath the skylight.  A more mundane doorway leads north, to the courtyard
before the entrance to the School proper.  

[Exits: north east south west down]

The magic mouth tells you, 'Are you ready to travel the portals?'
The magic mouth tells you, 'Just say the name of the direction you want to go to learn more.'

Dantaron Street
  Dantaron Street bisects the west half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the western gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the north, a large temple constructed of fine white marble
rises over the street.  To the south is a traveller's inn.

<310hp 172m 202mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]

Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the south is the central square of
Var Bandor.

Directions to Discount Guides of Var Bandor
===========================================
1. From the golden fountain, head south to the Chamber of Travel.
2. The portal to the east will take you to Var Bandor.
3. From the temple, head south once.
4. Head east until you see the fountain in Center Square.
5. Go north on Sadrent Road.  Go east at the first four-way
   intersection, onto Raddin Street.
6. Go east two rooms, and then go north into the shop.
7. Hire a guide from Arannia to take you to Jasa Lake.

Directions to the Tipsy Swordmaster:
====================================
1. From the golden fountain, head south to the Chamber of Travel.
2. The portal to the east will take you to Var Bandor.
3. From the temple, head south once.

   east until it dead-ends.

The Tipsy Swordmaster
  The Tipsy Swordmaster is a tavern frequented by the less wealthy
mercenary classes of Var Bandor.  Filled with thick smoke from tobacco
pipes, the large common room of the tavern is filled with the loud sounds of
drinking warriors.  Some scattered tables are filled with boisterous

some well-travelled doors, the street lies north.

n
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  Raddin Street
deadends at a stone wall to the east, and returns to the west.  North is a
run-down flophouse, and a large tavern to the south is decorated with a sign
proclaiming it to be the Tipsy Swordmaster.

<310hp 172m 212mv> 
s
A Dingy Office
  This one-room office is small and hopelessly seedy.  Dirty grey plaster
is cracked and bubbled in many places, stains and discolorations covering
the surface.  The roofbeams sag wearily, and the creaky floor is bowed and
warped.  Equally flimsy chairs are lined against the eastern wall.  The room
smells of damp and mold, and apparently hasn't been cleaned in years.  A
high desk, built to eliminate the need for a stool, sits opposite the
chairs.  An incredibly grimy window is made of dozens of thick, blurry panes
of cheap glass.  The window admits slightly less light than the open doorway
beside it which leads north out of the room.

Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the west, Iron Street leads into
the industrial section of Var Bandor, and to the east, Raddin street winds
through some run-down buildings.

s
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<310hp 172m 208mv> 
The Journey's End
  The Journey's End is a nice inn, though with closer examination you note
cobwebs that would not be present if this inn were in a more reputable part
of town.  A small bar stands in one corner, but most of the hard core
drinkers will go to one of the other numerous pubs along the road.  The
innkeeper stands behind the bar, accepting coin for his rooms upstairs, and
for food and drink alike.  The inn continues to the south, with more tables
for customers to sit down and relax, and there is a small door behind the
bar leading to the innkeeper's personal room.  North is the door back to the
bustle of Dantaron Road.

<310hp 172m 217mv> 
In the Tables
  The tables are scattered around the room in what seems to be a random
fashion, but there is still ample space for the barmaids to walk through to
set out food and drinks.  A large fireplace dominates the south wall, the
hearth is swept and ready for a warm fire during the winter.  A small
staircase leads upwards in the south-west corner of the room, to the
comfortable beds waiting for a weary customer to rest upon.  East are the
swinging doors leading to the kitchen, and north lies the entrance to the
inn.  

[Exits: north east up]
     A simple chessboard sits on a plain wooden table against the western wall.
Leaning back in his chair, a man enjoys a meaty chicken leg.
A haggard-looking man drowns his sorrows in a bottle of whisky.
A priestess of Alajial sits quietly nearly the fireplace.
A mother stands here, looking around for her son.

n
The Journey's End
  The Journey's End is a nice inn, though with closer examination you note
cobwebs that would not be present if this inn were in a more reputable part
of town.  A small bar stands in one corner, but most of the hard core
drinkers will go to one of the other numerous pubs along the road.  The
innkeeper stands behind the bar, accepting coin for his rooms upstairs, and
for food and drink alike.  The inn continues to the south, with more tables
for customers to sit down and relax, and there is a small door behind the
bar leading to the innkeeper's personal room.  North is the door back to the
bustle of Dantaron Road.  

[Exits: north (east) south]
The innkeeper bustles around the room, a warm welcoming smile on his round face.
A woman sits here, enjoying the peace of the inn.
A patron of the inn sits here, enjoying a fine meal.
A young boy sits here, spinning a brightly coloured top.

<310hp 172m 216mv> 
n
Dantaron Street
  Dantaron Street bisects the west half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the western gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the north, a large temple constructed of fine white marble
rises over the street.  To the south is a traveller's inn.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<310hp 172m 214mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A bedraggled orange tabby cat with a tattered ear and a mournful expression is here.
     A large marble fountain gurgles peacefully here.
A grey pigeon walks about tentatively, looking for scraps of food.
An armed enforcer of Var Bandor stands here.
An armed enforcer of Var Bandor stands here.

<310hp 172m 213mv> 
s
Ilrin Street
  A wide street composed of black stones and carefully-arranged curbs,
Ilrin Street runs the length of southern Var Bandor, winding among the
gloriously rich houses of the merchants and the eccentrically constructed
towers of the scholars.  Here and there, baskets of flowers hang from the
sides of buildings, and hired servants tend to shaped shrubs.  The streets
in the southern part of town are swept clean, and all animal traffic is
prohibited.  The Var Bandor Center Square is to the north.

Commerce Street
  Surrounded by newly constructed buildings, Commerce Street winds through
the merchant quarter of Var Bandor.  All around are signs of great wealth,
the gold that flows from the prosperous trade evident in the buildings, the
clothing of the citizens, and the meticulous maintenance of the streets.  To
the north is an elegant inn, and to the east is Ilrin Street.

The Bank of Var Bandor
  The most noticeable feature in the Bank is the line of teller windows
along the far wall.  The keen eyes of bankers peer out from behind the
barred windows, scrutinizing their clientele.  Plants and small wooden
benches provide the decor for those waiting for service, and a doorway leads
southwards onto Commerce Street.

Inside the Southern Gatehouse
  The southern gatehouse of Var Bandor is an elaborate affair,
well-maintained and proper.  A close watch is kept on the kind of traveler
allowed to enter the finest districts of the city, and a roster of those
banned from the area is kept nearby.  The immense granite walls rise to
either side of the gates, and to the south, the outskirts of Var Bandor run
into a thickly wooded area.  North, Ilrin Street leads into the heart of the
city.

A soldier of the Var Bandor Guard watches the gatehouse.

  You stand outside the southern wall of Var Bandor.  To the south, the

silvery lines of water a lush forested area is visible.  In the distance you
hear sounds of commerce, yelling and the noises of people working.

Trail into the Forest
  This trail winds its way southward, through the downland south of Var
Bandor, toward the Forest of Nendor.  The edges of the dirt path are lined
with smooth stones.  Stony grassland spreads to either side beyond the chalk
stone border, and the Nendorin woods spread before you to the south.  Back
northward the walls of Var Bandor are still visible, albeit barely.

The Forest Path
  A thin but well worn path winds through the forest of Nendor.  Stones
inscribed with odd runic markings dot the side of the path every now and
again, standing on the border between road and forest.  Large oaks line the
path on either side, leaves casting shade upon the path below.  The singing
of birds echoes through the forest, providing a constant murmur of sound.  The
path runs south from the north, leading deeper into the forest.  To the
east and west, breaks in the thick treeline are visible.

An Old Carriageway
  The faint trail to the south ends suddenly here, but not before it runs
into the remnants of an old carriageway.  This rutted track heads both east
and west from here, making a straight path through the deepening woods. 
From the thickness of the nettles and grass tussocks which stud the path,
and the occasional badger hole which breaches it, it would appear that the
carriageway hasn't been used in some time.

<310hp 172m 201mv> You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
By the Ivy-Covered Gate Posts
  The old carriageway continues south, passing between a pair of old,
stone gateposts.  The posts are of mortared bluestone blocks, roughly hewn,
and built into pinnacles some six feet high.  The gates themselves have long
since vanished, and all that remains of them are the heavy iron hinges,
bolted to the stone.  Thick ivy covers the gateposts, and the surrounding
shrubs almost completely obscure their presence.  To the south the path
continues through the trees, while on the northern side of the posts it
turns sharply west.  

[Exits: north south]

A Rutted Carriageway
  A rutted carriageway winds north and south here, between the trees of
Nendor forest.  Once cobbled with flat, white stones, the path is now badly
overgrown.  The stones are now pushed askew by grasses and saplings, or lie
buried in the mud which crowds in from the edges.  The leafy boughs of the
tall, slender trees hang over the carriage-way, forming a light tunnel.  To
the north the path passes some old gate posts, while to the south the trees
give way, revealing an ivy-covered manor house.  

[Exits: north south]

By the Doors of an Old Mansion
  Looming above you to the south is an old, stone mansion.  The building is
two stories high, with a tall bluestone tower set into the northwestern
corner. Most of this front face of the mansion is covered with thick ivy,
blending the building with the surrounding forest.  Only a few patches of
lichen-ridden stone look out from the ivy, and shattered windows high
overhead peer blankly at the tree-tops.  The carriageway, which leads north
into the forest, turns east here, and disappears around the side of the
mansion. A set of heavy oak doors hang loose on their hinges to the south.

A Rutted Carriageway, Beneath the Northern Face
  The carriageway runs beneath the front, northern face of an old,
ivy-covered mansion here.  This face of the mansion is intact, although
badly weathered, and a few shattered windows peek out from amidst the shroud
of green.  Looking through these windows, it seems that the rooms
immediately behind this wall have collapsed into ruin.  A little way to the
east the carriage-way turns around the side of the building and heads south,
while directly to the west it runs past the mansion's front door.  The thick
growth of the forest blocks the way north.

A Rutted Carriageway 
  The rutted carriageway passes beneath the ruined eastern side of the
mansion here.  The entire two stories of the building lie toppled in ruin
just to the west, and stones lie scattered across the path, moss-covered and

Before an Old Carriage House
  The overgrown carriageway comes to an end here, at the doors of a wooden

By an Old Oak Tree

A Path Torn Through the Forest
  A wide path has been torn through the forest here, as though by the
passage of some great beast.  Shrubs are rent aside, or simply crushed in
many cases, and low-hanging branches have been ripped from trees.  To the
west, a thick stand of blackberries lies in tatters from the passage.  To
the north is the rear of an old, wooden building, which seems to have been
the origin of the destruction, as a great hole gapes in the wall, and
shattered wood is strewn across the forest floor.  To the south, somewhat
downhill, stands another, larger wooden building.  A similar hole opens in
its northern wall.

A Junk-Filled Storeroom
  The rear room of this caretaker's cottage has been converted to a storage

recall
North Wall of the Temple of Darkness
  Earendam's temple of darkness is an architectural hybrid, blending the
classical Republican forms with the statuery of Yithoul and the intricate
carvings of the Srryn.  The temple is topped by a barrel-vaulted roof, which
leads from the southern entrance towards the altar which sits here against
the north wall.  Supporting the ceiling are a series of onyx columns, whose
intricate carvings serve to frame a set of statues in marble, forming a sort
of gallery along the east and west walls.  The altar here is made from
carved ebony, cunningly crafted with the symbols of the order which tends
this temple.  Set on the altar are smoldering censers, which fill the
surrounding air with the smell of myrrh.  

[Exits: east south]
(White Aura) A priest of the Aklaju offers the services of the dark gods.

Kaagn Row
  Kaagn row heads east and west along the north banks of the Dantaron, a
road paved with well-worn cobblestones hewn from the Brintors.  Pylons block
off the way to the south, except where a high arched wooden bridge splits
off from the road to cross the Dantaron.  The entirety of the north side of
the street is taken up with a temple of blocks carved from obsidian.  Tall
black steps lead up to the entrance, which is framed by columns, which have
all been carved into complicated piece of statuery.  The tall columns give
the building a gigantic feel, and it seems to tower over the entire street.

The Dantaron River
  The placid waters of the Dantaron make their way through the city of
Earendam.  Passing between the city's mercantile district to the north, and
the old city to the south, the river is one of the principal avenues for
trade into and out of the city.  The waters of the Dantaron are deep here,
clouded by the dark mud of its bottom, and the frequent river-traffic along
its course.  To the east, the Dantaron flows under a high arched bridge. 
Westward, it flows towards its egress from the city's walls.

Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.

<332hp 177m 77mv> 
s
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

The Journey's End
  The Journey's End is a nice inn, though with closer examination you note
cobwebs that would not be present if this inn were in a more reputable part
of town.  A small bar stands in one corner, but most of the hard core
drinkers will go to one of the other numerous pubs along the road.  The
innkeeper stands behind the bar, accepting coin for his rooms upstairs, and
for food and drink alike.  The inn continues to the south, with more tables
for customers to sit down and relax, and there is a small door behind the
bar leading to the innkeeper's personal room.  North is the door back to the
bustle of Dantaron Road.

help rules
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Rules of Avendar                                                 |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Avendar is a MUD that supports roleplaying, player versus environment
(PvE), and player versus player (PvP) modes of play.  This page will discuss
what that means and what our expectations with regards to behavior are. 
These standards and guidelines apply to players and staff alike. 
Individuals that violate these guidelines will face penalties ranging from
uncomfortable conversations to denial to removal of all privileges and
access to the game entirely.  

Avendar is not a business or a service and we do not have customers.  This
is a hobby which we invite others to enjoy with us in a space we curate. 
Every part of the game will always be free, and no advantage will ever be
offered to a player character for donations given to assist Avendar in its
operation costs.  

The atmosphere we want to cultivate is that of a group of acquaintances
coming together at a person's house to play a tabletop adventure game with a
big roleplaying aspect, such as Pathfinder.  Even as our characters may
engage in conflicts both along and against one another, those should not
influence how we treat one another around the table, so to speak.  We don't
have to be best friends, but we expect civility and for people to refrain
from behavior that is malicious, harmful, or unsportsmanlike.  If you aren't
sure whether something is going to be a problem, ask.  If something
genuinely bothers to you, politely bring it up either directly or with a
staff member.  This applies to every space within the locus of our control,
including the Avendar game itself, the official Discord server, and this
wiki.  

We have no interest in developing an exhaustive and specific list of things
you can and cannot do and instead advise you use all of the above as a
guideline.  That said, this is a short list of activities which are
egregiously unacceptable, and will get you immediately denied and/or
banned:

* Any expression of real-world bigotry including but not limited to racism,
misogyny, homophobia, or transphobia
* Pedophilia or explicit child sexual material of any kind
* Explicit depictions or discussions of rape or sexual assault
* Out-of-character stalking, harassment, or bullying, regardless of where it
happens

In general, we emphasize remembering that there are real people that will be
reading whatever you write within the game.  As we detail in HELP
ROLEPLAYING, we do not shy away from scenes or stories about difficult
subjects, but we do expect it to be approached in a way that is responsible
and respectful of others.  For more detailed information about what that
entails, please read HELP ROLEPLAYING.  

While PvP is uncommon, whenever you are logged in there is a chance you will
become engaged in PvP with another player which may result in the death of
your character and the theft of that character's items.  Murder and theft
are permitted and encouraged forms of play.  Staff will not intervene in or
adjudicate in-character conflicts between player characters.  We expect
those who engage in PvP to behave in a way that is sportsmanlike and fair;
behaviors such as (but not limited to) timing your log-ins to avoid
retribution or deliberately targeting new players will not be tolerated.  

The game environment including the world and mechanics of Avendar are
provided to you as-is to enjoy and may be incomplete or buggy.  Knowingly
abusing an exploit for any reason will result in all of a player's current
characters being denied and, depending on the severity, being banned from
the game entirely.  

See also: HELP ROLEPLAYING, HELP BACKGROUND, HELP DESCRIPTION, HELP MULTICHAR

misogyny, homophobia, or transphobia
* Pedophilia or explicit child sexual material of any kind
* Explicit depictions or discussions of rape or sexual assault
* Out-of-character stalking, harassment, or bullying, regardless of where it
happens

In general, we emphasize remembering that there are real people that will be
reading whatever you write within the game.  As we detail in HELP
ROLEPLAYING, we do not shy away from scenes or stories about difficult
subjects, but we do expect it to be approached in a way that is responsible
and respectful of others.  For more detailed information about what that
entails, please read HELP ROLEPLAYING.  

While PvP is uncommon, whenever you are logged in there is a chance you will
become engaged in PvP with another player which may result in the death of
your character and the theft of that character's items.  Murder and theft
are permitted and encouraged forms of play.  Staff will not intervene in or
adjudicate in-character conflicts between player characters.  We expect
those who engage in PvP to behave in a way that is sportsmanlike and fair;
behaviors such as (but not limited to) timing your log-ins to avoid
retribution or deliberately targeting new players will not be tolerated.  

The game environment including the world and mechanics of Avendar are
provided to you as-is to enjoy and may be incomplete or buggy.  Knowingly
abusing an exploit for any reason will result in all of a player's current
characters being denied and, depending on the severity, being banned from
the game entirely.  

See also: HELP ROLEPLAYING, HELP BACKGROUND, HELP DESCRIPTION, HELP MULTICHAR

In the Tables
  The tables are scattered around the room in what seems to be a random
fashion, but there is still ample space for the barmaids to walk through to
set out food and drinks.  A large fireplace dominates the south wall, the
hearth is swept and ready for a warm fire during the winter.  A small
staircase leads upwards in the south-west corner of the room, to the
comfortable beds waiting for a weary customer to rest upon.  East are the
swinging doors leading to the kitchen, and north lies the entrance to the
inn.  

[Exits: north east up]
     A simple chessboard sits on a plain wooden table against the western wall.

A haggard-looking man drowns his sorrows in a bottle of whisky.
A priestess of Alajial sits quietly nearly the fireplace.
A mother stands here, looking around for her son.

The Journey's End
  The Journey's End is a nice inn, though with closer examination you note
cobwebs that would not be present if this inn were in a more reputable part
of town.  A small bar stands in one corner, but most of the hard core
drinkers will go to one of the other numerous pubs along the road.  The
innkeeper stands behind the bar, accepting coin for his rooms upstairs, and
for food and drink alike.  The inn continues to the south, with more tables
for customers to sit down and relax, and there is a small door behind the
bar leading to the innkeeper's personal room.  North is the door back to the
bustle of Dantaron Road.  

[Exits: north (east) south]

Dantaron Street
  Dantaron Street bisects the west half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the western gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the north, a large temple constructed of fine white marble
rises over the street.  To the south is a traveller's inn.

Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

<325hp 187m 223mv> 
e
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way

founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become

Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned
with a sword calls attention to the weapon shop to the south.  Raddin street
continues to the east, while the main drag of Sadrent road opens to the
west.

<352hp 203m 223mv> 
s
A Run-Down Weaponry
  This small store is particularly cramped and showing of age.  The ceiling
is cracked across the center, and the paint and plaster look aged and in
some need of repair.  Despite this, examples of the shop's unusual wares
hang along the walls on display, made primarily of wood and iron.  Weapons
of all types are arrayed throughout the shop, leaning or mounted.  The floor
is worn and rickety, and the shop's main counter is battered and worn from
years of sales.  Smaller work can be done in a small kiln in the back room,
but that seems more for repairs or modifications than to create the massive
wares the shop sells.  Raddin Street lies through the door to the north.  

[Exits: north]
A grizzled, scarred alatharya works within the shop.
