A Stone Stairwell
  A stone stairwell leads upward toward the fifth floor, just on the other
side of the large tiled arena of the fourth.  The arched windows and heavy
construction suggest that this is one of the oldest remaining parts of the
Tower of Testing, the stone worn smooth by a thousand years of young
adventurers.  The stairs are smooth and even, and worn in the center from
the crossing of many footsteps.  Torches light the stairwell, giving it the
same shadowy cast as some of the lowest floors of the School and Tower.  The
fifth floor awaits above, while the tests of battle are to the west.  

[Exits: west up]

The Fifth Floor
  The fifth floor is among the oldest parts of the Tower of Testing, built
of heavy, rough-hewn stone.  The arched windows and smooth, worn stone
suggest the passage of untold adventurers over many generations, the floor
clear of debris and signs of disrepair.  Old stains of blood mark the stone
walls, and heavy iron lanterns hang from the ceiling to light the corridor. 
A large door leads to the south, its frame secure and marked with runic
wards.  The stairwell lies to the north, while this level of the Tower
awaits behind the southern door.

The Fifth Floor
  The fifth floor is among the oldest parts of the Tower of Testing, built
of heavy, rough-hewn stone.  The arched windows and smooth, worn stone
suggest the passage of untold adventurers over many generations, the floor
clear of debris and signs of disrepair.  Old stains of blood mark the stone
walls, and heavy iron lanterns hang from the ceiling to light the corridor. 
A long slit in the eastern wall glitters with sharp points, a mounted
barrage of daggers waiting for the unwary.  A large door leads to the north,
its frame secure and marked with runic wards.  The fifth level continues
through a shimmering portal set into the south wall.  

[Exits: north south]

A Small Granite Chamber
  This stone chamber is built from smooth blocks of pale granite, four
bracketed torches ensconced on each wall.  The ceiling is high and largely
oddly disorienting, as the floor and walls are all the same color and
texture.  The air is cool and crisp, tinged with a hint of magical energy. 
There are no apparent exits in any direction, making the low ceiling seem
even more claustrophobic.

A Lavish Enclosure
  On the other side of the magic mouth's portal is a lavishly decorated
chamber, which appears to be the highest level of the Tower of Testing.  The
walls largely absent, the high roof held aloft by mighty stone columns.  A
barrier of energy surrounds the enclosure, allowing the passing breeze and
cool air of the Tower's great height.  The marble floor is covered in a
rich, burgundy carpet, with gold-mounted orbs of light illuminating the
room.  The view outside is little more than a cloudscape, with the sun and
moons clearly visible to occupants.  The chamber continues to the south.

A Lavish Enclosure
  Before you is a lavishly decorated chamber, which appears to be the
highest level of the Tower of Testing.  The walls largely absent, the high
roof held aloft by mighty stone columns.  A barrier of energy surrounds the
enclosure, allowing the passing breeze and cool air of the Tower's great
height.  The marble floor is covered in a rich, burgundy carpet, with
gold-mounted orbs of light illuminating the room.  The view outside is
little more than a cloudscape, with the sun and moons clearly visible to
occupants.  A well-polished desk sits within the enclosure, a large array of
scrolls, books, and other materials piled at either side.  A golden spiral
staircase heads up onto the roof itself, while the chamber continues to the
north.

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Roof of the Tower of Testing
  The high roof of the Tower is shielded by a barely perceptible field of
magic, but otherwise is entirely unencumbered.  It includes a large central
platform, upon which six slender spires rise, matching a convex hexagon's
points.  The golden staircase from below arrives between two of such spires,
allowing admission to the platform.  The glittering stone of the rooftop
shines in both sunlight and moonlight, and the shrill wind whips between the
spires.  The surrounding skyscape is above the clouds, their wispy expanse
making the roof seem more like an island in a white sea.  A large orb sits
at the center of the platform, beckoning you.  The only apparent exit is
down the golden stairs.  

[Exits: down]
A marble statue of a scholar stands silently beside the central orb.
The marble scholar brands you with the Sigil of the School of Heroes.
Obtain the School Sigil is complete!
Return to Jimacha in The School of Heroes to collect your reward.

A Small Delivery Office
  This small office is walled with the same white-stone blocks as are used
in the Hall of Arms and lined with similar iron sconces.  It is decorated
with hanging burgundy tapestries, giving it a richer, more mercantile feel. 
A small wooden desk and chair sit against the western wall, bearing a tiny
inkwell and quill-stand.  The ceiling is low and plain, the light from the
sconces playing across its uneven surface.  Open doorways lead out of the
office to the north and south, with the northern portal shimmering with
magical energy.

Before the Gates of the School of Heroes
  Before you stand the gates of the School of Heroes, the renowned center
of training for young adventurers.  It is an enormous structure, composed of
marble, stone, and brick, and has been built upon a rocky hill.  The gates
are forged of wrought iron, and remain open to travelers of every size,
affiliation, and creed.  The central foyer of the School lies ahead, the
marble edifice looming over its well-worn gates.  A small courtyard opens
here, with a beautiful central fountain and a circle of low bushes.  

[Exits: north south]
     A beautiful golden fountain gushes water.

Inside the Gates
  Past the wrought iron gates is a wide corridor with walls cut from solid
granite blocks, lit by mounted white globes.  The entry corridor is
surprisingly simple for such a vast and well-known establishment, as it
bears no notable ornamentation.  The School's foyer awaits to the north,
opening up from the corridor's enclosure into a vast chamber.  To the south
lies the School's entrance.  

[Exits: north south]
(?) (White Aura) An aging gate guard stands here, welcoming new arrivals.

<285hp 172m 213mv> 
n
The Foyer of the School of Heroes
  The School of Heroes begins with a grand foyer, complete with a vaulted
ceiling held aloft by great marble columns.  The room is spacious and airy,
with high, white marble walls and mounted, shining globes to provide light. 
Two great marble stairways sit back, just off center toward the room's north
side.  One ascends to an upper level of the School, and spirals about a
great glass pillar as it rises.  A well-made desk sits not far from the
foyer's entrance, giving the receptionist an opportunity to greet new
students.  The other descends to a lower level, and voices echo from its
depths.  Three halls open to the north, east, and west, leading to other
branches of the School.  The corridor to the south leads to the School's
iron gates.  

A large sign sits off to one side, offering directions to students.

[Exits: north east south west up down]

grounds.'
Jimacha tells you, 'Oh, and go see Shiguln, who guards the Hall of Victors.  He'll let you pass
now.'

<285hp 172m 212mv> 
d
The Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower
of Testing.  This space, however, is known as the Adventurer's Lounge, which
is a large, open expanse.  It is filled with chairs, couches, and other
furniture, allowing students of the School to gather, converse, or join
together.  The walls are made older, darker stones than the floor above, but
are lit by similar iron sconces.  The floor is hardwood, rather than tile,
to dampen the clatter of steps.  The lounge continues to the north and east,
while the foyer of the School of Heroes is up a flight of marble stairs.  A
chamber lies to the south, home to the School's mascot.  

A sign stands near the stairwell.  

[Exits: north east south up]
A caladaran pupil ponders the meaning of one of his book's passages.

The Bar in the Adventurer's Lounge
  The lower level of the School of Heroes serves as a gathering place for
young adventurers, as well as an entry point to the Hall of Trials and Tower

<285hp 172m 210mv> 
e
The Entrance to the Hall of Victors
  This spur off of the Adventurer's Lounge leads to a tremendous archway. 
It is particularly ancient, even for the School, and is marked by
now-unreadable druidic markings.  Whatever the original use for this
still-standing arch, the long-forgotten laborers who built the School used
it as a transition into another underground Hall.  Named the Hall of
Victors, it is designed to reward those who complete the School's many
trials.  The wooden floor of the west gives way to a rough-hewn stone not
altogether unlike the Tower of Testing, creating a regal but imposing
effect.  Two mounted globes of light illuminate the archway.  The Hall's
interior lies east, while the lounge is to the west.  

A small note is tacked to the archway.

[Exits: east west]
A grey-skinned giant blocks the eastern passage.

The Hall of Victors
  The Hall of Victors houses the emissary of the family of the School of
Heroes' illustrious founder, and it is his task to reward those valiant
young adventurers who complete the Tower of Testing.  The rough-hewn stone
of the arched entryway gives way to a set of two large steps, and then a
large, circular platform made of polished tiles.  The walls transition
almost immediately into the School's characteristic marble.  The entrance to
the Hall of Victors lies to the west, while an opulent chamber lies to the
south in its interior.  

A huge statue stands at the center of the platform, depicting a stylized man
and woman.  

[Exits: south west]

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
An Exotic Parlor in the Hall of Victors
  A great octagonal room, this sumptuous parlor opens up to a fantastically
high ceiling.  Many thick, blood-red drapes shroud the marblework of its
walls, giving it a great tent-like atmosphere.  Just above the sturdy bronze
rodding that holds the drapery aloft, the ceiling slopes upward into a
sharp, open-topped steeple.  A number of polished, dull orbs of light line
the interior of the steeple's high point, the bronze chains that dangle
beneath them glittering like tiny stars.  Against the south wall, a massive
and ornate divan dominates the room, its elaborate designs only heightening
the general exoticism.  Much of the floor is covered by a circular farsh
rug, covering the polished Harrudim tile beneath it.  The scents of spice
hang in the dim, smoky air, giving the parlor an even more opulent flair.  

[Exits: north]

way.'

Zebenar Kinest tells you, 'Since I doubt you know the way, these directions will lead you to her
shop.'

l directions
Directions to Discount Guides of Var Bandor
===========================================
1. From the golden fountain, head south to the Chamber of Travel.
2. The portal to the east will take you to Var Bandor.
3. From the temple, head south once.
4. Head east until you see the fountain in Center Square.
5. Go north on Sadrent Road.  Go east at the first four-way
   intersection, onto Raddin Street.
6. Go east two rooms, and then go north into the shop.
7. Hire a guide from Arannia to take you to Jasa Lake.

A Spiral Stairway
  Just above the foyer to the School of Heroes is a spiraling stairwell
leading upward.  It follows a central glass pillar, whose translucent
interior offers a variety of frozen stone replicas of birds, insects, and
winged beasts.  At its core is a marvelous sculpture of a dragon, donated by
the Glallian School in Earendam.  There are no external walls, but rather, a
sturdy handrail which follows the stairs' outer edge.  The lights of the
foyer glitter below, and the marble columns parallel the rise of the
stairwell's interior pillar.  A three way junction awaits above, while the
foyer is below.

The Hall of Fates
  The spiral stairwell rises up into a three-way junction, its cloudy glass
central column rising to the ceiling.  The stones here are older and more

<302hp 172m 205mv> 
e
The Portal Chamber
  This cubical room is made from blocks of hewn marble.  Benches of similar
stone are set diagonally against the corners of the room, and an open
skylight provides illumination from above.  However, this room is unique in
that it contains four magical gateways which connect the School of Heroes to
various locations in Avendar.  Each glowing with soft blue light, the three
vertical portals are set into the eastern, western, and southern walls.  The
fourth portal is horizontal and circular, and is set into the floor directly
beneath the skylight.  A more mundane doorway leads north, to the courtyard
before the entrance to the School proper.  

[Exits: north east south west down]

The magic mouth tells you, 'Are you ready to travel the portals?'
The magic mouth tells you, 'Just say the name of the direction you want to go to learn more.'

<309hp 172m 214mv> 
Dantaron Street
  Dantaron Street bisects the west half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the western gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the north, a large temple constructed of fine white marble
rises over the street.  To the south is a traveller's inn.

<309hp 172m 212mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<309hp 172m 207mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned
with a sword calls attention to the weapon shop to the south.  Raddin street
continues to the east, while the main drag of Sadrent road opens to the
west.

The Wench's Lute
  This shop lies just off of the east end of Raddin Street, and is exactly

boarded over, and the other is made of bubbled, foggy glass.  An imitation

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
A Dingy Office
  This one-room office is small and hopelessly seedy.  Dirty grey plaster
is cracked and bubbled in many places, stains and discolorations covering
the surface.  The roofbeams sag wearily, and the creaky floor is bowed and
warped.  Equally flimsy chairs are lined against the eastern wall.  The room
smells of damp and mold, and apparently hasn't been cleaned in years.  A
high desk, built to eliminate the need for a stool, sits opposite the
chairs.  An incredibly grimy window is made of dozens of thick, blurry panes
of cheap glass.  The window admits slightly less light than the open doorway
beside it which leads north out of the room.  

[Exits: north]

Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.

Outside the Northern Gatehouse
  The towering gates of Var Bandor rise to the south.  Huge, heavy wooden
doors reinforced with iron bars, the gates are maintained rigorously.  The
walls to the east and west are solid stone, with murder slits.  To the

Bandor on either side.

A Small Shrine on a Hill

Jaras Square
  The center of the lazy village, Jaras Square is by far the most lively
area of town.  Nearly surrounded by houses, this small paved square is home
to a meager wooden fountain which provides the villagers with fresh potable
water.  The shanties that line the square seem to stare at the fountain
blankly, their mildewy facades yawning.  The relatively large building to
the east is the most modern of the buildings, a ragged, poorly carved wooden
leaf hanging above its door.  The pavement of the square hugs closely to the
base of the fountain.  The hard-packed muddy ground of the village continues
to the north, south, and west.

Rehaeda's Parlor
  This large parlor room is by far one of the most elaborate in the Jaras
community, but remains spartan by even caladaran standards.  Its wooden
walls are painted a soothing green color, a testament to the extravagance
found here.  A large assortment of herbs lies across the long, unpainted
counter, each set into its own small compartment.  The ceiling's rafters had
at one point been left uncovered, but leaves and vines have grown up to
cover them.  A single candled sconce hangs on the wall, bathing the room in
a soft luminescense.  Another room lies, mostly cordonned off, to the east,
while the central square of the city lies westward.

A Grassy Marsh
  This grassy area seems to have been trampled and let grow back a number
of times.  The ground and flora are uneven with the marks of many
footprints, most of which have been made by birds and other small animals.

visible along that path.

A Reedy Marsh
  The plantlife grows so thickly here that it is difficult to pass through
it without creating a large amount of rustling noise.  Standing nearly eight
feet in places, the reeds have become a home to many animals, as can be seen
by the slither marks and small footprints left in the mud, and the sounds
that seem to come from some ambient source.  The reeds thin a little to give

is here to the west, toward the body of the lake, while a small path is
barely visible through the growth to the north.

The Splendid Temple of Ayaunj
  The grand atrium of the Splendid Temple of Ayaunj opens all sides, its
high fan-vaulted ceilings held aloft by fluted Gaaldic columns above a
resplendent golden marble floor, everything in sight glittering under a
massive, radiant Gaaldic chandelier.  Private offices and meeting rooms ring
the vast open floor on two tiers, rented by barrister-priests or visiting
merchants as they conduct every conceivable kind of business.  Spiraling
stairs lead up to the second tier and down to the basement, and guards
linger inconspicuously near every egress.

A Well-Trod Path
  The gates to the port city of Gaald are an iron-wrought work of artistry
that seem more for show than defense, featuring a stylized eagle over a
ship.  The thick granite frame and walls are encroached upon by ivy.  To the
north and east, a well-worn path curves along the outskirts of the city,
equidistant from the walls and the rocky shoreline of the Gaald peninsula. 
Through the gates to the south, the sounds of bustling commerce from the
trader houses and markets can be heard.  A less-used trail leads west, while
a sprawling estate can be spotted past tall fieldstone walls to the north.

A Trail to the Lighthouse
  This trail is quite old; the earth is packed solid from countless years
of footsteps.  Heavy stones have been pounded into it, providing a path
which would survive the frequent rain of the Gaald peninsula.  To the south,
the ivy-covered granite walls of the city guard its edge, while the walls of

<154hp 188m 135mv> A Bridge Over the Fortfo River
  A sandy ocean shore stretches to the north and south, surrounding the
beaten path that travels parallel to the shoreline a ways to the west.  Few
if any remnants of the thick oak forests to the northeast remain, replaced
instead by pebbles, shale, and fallen boulders from the towering Yagash
mountains far to the east.  A stone bridge allows a view of the Fortfo River
snaking down the Yagashes and gently curving through farmland before
traveling under the bridge and spilling into the estuary to the west.  Far
off to the southwest, a small peninsula juts forth from the shoreline, and a
small town sits atop it.  At either side of the bridge, a path is deeply
grooved and spotted with tracks of animals, people, and caravans of goods,
and stretches to the north and south.

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
A Path Through the Plains
  An old track winds northward across the vast Arien Plains.  This
ill-travelled path is little more than a shallow depression in the clayish
earth, grown now with the sparse brambles and spiny tussocks which stud the
flatlands.  A pale, twisting thread, the track can be seen meandering for
miles before being engulfed in the unchanging greyness of the land.  The
track ends to the south, where it meets a dirt road which cuts the plains
from east to west.  Beyond this road in the distance, a silvery-blue ribbon,
the Dantaron River arcs northward to meet Var Bandor, whose walls can be
seen far to the southeast.  

[Exits: north south]

A Path Through the Plains
  An old track winds north and south across the vast Arien Plains.  This
ill-travelled path is little more than a shallow depression in the clayish
earth, grown now with the sparse brambles and spiny tussocks which stud the
flatlands.  A pale, twisting thread, the track can be seen meandering for
miles before being engulfed in the unchanging greyness of the land.  The
plains meet the sky at the horizon far to the east and south.  To the north
and west, dark lines border plain and sky, where the great forests lie.

Approaching a Forest
  As the land rises to the north, the plains abandon their level march and
roll like great grassy dunes.  Each rounded rise is capped with small
growths of oak, smattered with red-berried rowan.  The ground grows more
rugged and forested to the north, and little rivulets flow from the higher
land, disappearing amidst reedy marshes in the shallow valleys.  To the
south the plains flatten and stretch away endlessly.

A Young Forest
  The surrounding forest has been allowed to encroach upon this part of the
village.  Where once a yard stretched back from the stone house to the
north, now young trees grow.  An old wooden fence, all but collapsed,
surrounds the area.  Here and there a rusty farm implement lies half buried
in the rich soil.  To the west, through an old wooden gate in the tumbled
fence, lies the village path.  To the east a cleared yard lies, above which
a grey plume of smoke rises.

<168hp 188m 127mv> 
e
You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Charcoal-burner's Yard
  From the soot-stained wall of a stone house to the north, to the
impinging oak forest to the south stretches a long muddy yard.  A spire of
thick, grey smoke rises from a structure in the center of the yard, and
breaks into a helical plume as it reached the high breezes over the village.
The occasional gust of wind down from the forest canopy sends smoke swirling
about the yard.  The source of the smoke is a high mound, built in the
center of a broad, shallow depression.  The mound is covered in earth, but
at its base the inner structure of the mound can be seen - layer upon layer
of wooden logs.  Heat radiates from the entire mound, and the wood at the
base is blackened and charred.  Against the wall of the house, beneath a
narrow shelter, hang large, bulging, burlap sacks.  A wooden door leads
north into the house.  To the west, over a tumbled down fence, the forest
has overtaken the neighbouring yard.  

[Exits: north west]

  The tanner's yard is cluttered with all sorts of junk.  From the tanner's
house to the north stretches a canopy of hide across about half the yard. 
Beneath this canopy, protected from the elements, sit three large vats of
foul smelling substances.  Newly tanned leathers hang above the vats, drying
in the breeze.  Benches, tools, building materials and an overturned
wheelbarrow are scattered about haphazardly.

on the side of the path and between the houses, bathing the village in
shades of red and green.  To the east, a gate hangs loosely in a tumbled

A Young Forest
  The surrounding forest has been allowed to encroach upon this part of the
village.  Where once a yard stretched back from the stone house to the
north, now young trees grow.  An old wooden fence, all but collapsed,
surrounds the area.  Here and there a rusty farm implement lies half buried
in the rich soil.  To the west, through an old wooden gate in the tumbled
fence, lies the village path.  To the east a cleared yard lies, above which
a grey plume of smoke rises.

<359hp 188m 227mv> The Charcoal-burner's Yard
  From the soot-stained wall of a stone house to the north, to the
impinging oak forest to the south stretches a long muddy yard.  A spire of
thick, grey smoke rises from a structure in the center of the yard, and
breaks into a helical plume as it reached the high breezes over the village.
The occasional gust of wind down from the forest canopy sends smoke swirling
about the yard.  The source of the smoke is a high mound, built in the
center of a broad, shallow depression.  The mound is covered in earth, but
at its base the inner structure of the mound can be seen - layer upon layer
of wooden logs.  Heat radiates from the entire mound, and the wood at the
base is blackened and charred.  Against the wall of the house, beneath a
narrow shelter, hang large, bulging, burlap sacks.  A wooden door leads
north into the house.  To the west, over a tumbled down fence, the forest
has overtaken the neighbouring yard.  

[Exits: north west]

A Wooden House
  This run-down old house of wood and stone seems comfortable enough
inside.  A small bed stands unmade against one wall, and a couple of wooden
stools stand squat by a stone hearth.  A well blackened kettle hangs over a
small pile of smouldering coals and ash, steaming gently.  Next to the
hearth in the northern wall is a large wooden box for firewood.  Windows set
in the south and east walls reveal the thick forest outside, which presses
in against the little cottage.  In the western wall is set a door.

The Eaves of a Forest
  The land here forms a tight network of shallow valleys and ridges,
channelling little rivulets into the flattening plains to the south.  The
trees grow more densely as the land rises to the north, the oak and rowan
becoming mixed with tall-growing white birch.  To the south the land drops

s
Approaching a Forest
  As the land rises to the north, the plains abandon their level march and
roll like great grassy dunes.  Each rounded rise is capped with small
growths of oak, smattered with red-berried rowan.  The ground grows more
rugged and forested to the north, and little rivulets flow from the higher
land, disappearing amidst reedy marshes in the shallow valleys.  To the
south the plains flatten and stretch away endlessly.  

[Exits: north south]

s
<359hp 188m 209mv> 
A Path Through the Plains
  An old track winds north and south across the vast Arien Plains.  This
ill-travelled path is little more than a shallow depression in the clayish
earth, grown now with the sparse brambles and spiny tussocks which stud the
flatlands.  A pale, twisting thread, the track can be seen meandering for
miles before being engulfed in the unchanging greyness of the land.  The
plains meet the sky at the horizon far to the east and south.  To the north
and west, dark lines border plain and sky, where the great forests lie.  

[Exits: north south]

help description
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Descriptions                                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Description + <line> : Add a line to your description
Description -        : Remove a line from your description
Description clear    : Clears your description completely
Description          : Shows your description
Description edit     : Edit your description completely*

* It is strongly recommended that you read Help EDIT before you use
this command. 

The DESCRIPTION command allows you to describe your character.

Your description should show people what you look like, no more,
no less.  Comments about your character's personality or history
should be reserved for in character interactions and your background.
Responses to the look should also be reserved for in character
interaction.

A description is MANDATORY by the 10th level. If you do not have a 
description by this time, expect to be detained by an immortal until 
you do.

You can also add keywords to your description, allowing people
to look at a particular thing you reference. For more help on
this, see help EXDESC.

See also: BACKGROUND EDITOR EXDESC FORMAT

<359hp 188m 211mv>

<359hp 188m 211mv> 
help move
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Movement                                                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Your movement, or moves, represents your character's stamina in travelling
long distances. If your movement ever drops to zero, you will be unable to
move. (Rest or sleep to restore lost movement). Differing terrain requires
different amount of movement to move a single square. 


<359hp 188m 233mv> 
help 
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Avendar: The Crucible of Legends -- Help                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

You can get a help on a variety of topics to guide you through the playing
of Avendar.  Simply type help '<subject>' to gain help on a certain topic.
Here's a list of general topics you can search for help on to get you
started:

GETTING STARTED - The basics of Avendar and MUDding in general.
INFORMATION - How to get info on yourself and your surroundings.
MOVING AROUND - How to move around in the world of Avendar.
INTERACTION - How to interact with objects and items in Avendar.
COMMUNICATION - How to communicate with others in Avendar.
GROUPING - How to group together with others in Avendar.
COMBAT - How to engage (and survive!) combat in Avendar.
OVERVIEW - An overview of the basic Avendar commands (old help).

Be sure to pay attention to the "See Also" located at the bottom of many of
the helpfiles, as they often point to other useful pieces of information on
the topic you're reading on.

If you are stuck or confused and cannot find help on a certain topic, please
read 'help PRAY' for instructions on how to contact an immortal who may be
able to help you.

<359hp 188m 232mv> 
help prompt
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Prompt                                                           |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Syntax: prompt
Syntax: prompt all
Syntax: prompt <%*>
Syntax: defaultprompt <%*>

PROMPT with out an argument will turn your prompt on or off.

PROMPT ALL will give you the standard "<hits mana moves>" prompt.

PROMPT <%*> where the %* are the various variables you may set yourself.

        %% :  Display the % character 
        %h :  Display your current hits
        %H :  Display your maximum hits
        %m :  Display your current mana
        %M :  Display your maximum mana
        %v :  Display your current moves
        %V :  Display your maximum moves
        %x :  Display your current experience
        %X :  Display experience to level
        %p :  Display your current exploration points
        %P :  Display exploration points required
        %a :  Display your alignment
        %r :  Display the room name you are in
        %l :  Display current language spoken
        %t :  Display current gametime in hh:mm format
        %e :  Display the exits from the room in NESWDU style
        %c :  Display a carriage return (useful for multi-line prompts)
        %s :  Display your current position
        %T :  Display the terrain of the room you are in.
        %d :  Display the light/dark status of the room you are in.

Example:  PROMPT <%hhp %mm %vmv>
        Will set your prompt to "<10hp 100m 100mv>"

DEFAULTPROMPT <%*> will set a prompt that all new characters created on the
same account will use.

Prompts may be colourized using the codes contained in help EXCOLOUR.

the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.  

[Exits: east west]

The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north out of the Arien
Plains, now giving way to the rolling foothills of the Brintor Mountains. 
The low scrub bushes that populated the praries are now interspersed with
struggling evergreens and patches of rough grass.  Far to the north you can
make out the outline of the Brintor peaks against the sky.  A small side
path, formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels, leads toward a small
cluster of hills to the east.

The West Gate of Earendam
  Earendam's west gates are made of sturdy iron, built between two tall
stone pillars.  Reinforcing these gates are several stout bars of iron,
treated to preserve them from wear.  Outside the gates, the Arien Road heads
west, cutting across the plains which give it its namesake.  Inside, the
Arien Plaza opens, marking the beginning of Earendam proper.

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Western Arien Plaza
  The Arien Plaza comes to an end here as it approaches the western gate of
Earendam.  Travelers and merchants head out through this gate onto the
Arien road, bringing goods to and from the lands to the west.  Set in the
northwestern portion of the city, this plaza is a square ringed on all
sides by the buildings and walls of New Earendam.  Paved with cobblestones
long worn smooth by the feet of travelers entering the city from the Arien
road, the center of the square lies eastward, where an ornate fountain
serves as a resting place for the main body of the populace in the immediate
area.  Shops line the northern edge of the square, while southward the plaza
eventually terminates in a stone wall.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A hulking alatharya porter carries goods for a merchant.
A merchant from Var Bandor strolls through the plaza.

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Center of Arien Plaza
  The Arien plaza stretches in all directions around this point.  From
here, you can make out the locations on the periphery of this almost
perfectly square plaza.  Travelers head to and from a gate to the west,
filling the square with merchants and others, passing through the city by
way of the Arien road.  Further east, the square eventually leads to the
eastern portion of the city, while a similar passage cuts through a wall a
ways to the south.  The north wall of the plaza is dominated by a series of
shops and taverns, mainly devoted to providing for the merchants who pass
through here.  The exact center of the plaza houses a sizeable granite
fountain, its circular base surrounding a pool whose water source is a
statue of tall caladaran.  The cobblestone ground of the plaza bears shows
many signs of wear and use, the fountain being a popular gathering place for
merchants newly arrived in the city.  A small, square grate sits at the
eastern side of the base of the fountain.  

[Exits: north east south west (down)]
A muscular protector is loitering here, surveying the area casually.

Anteroom of the Arien Way
  This small hallway serves as the anteroom for the Arien Way, a popular
tavern in this part of Earendam.  Covered in panelled pine, the walls of the
hallway narrow in a doorway to the north, leading to the interior of the
tavern.  Covering the floor of the anteroom is a tiled mosaic, depicting the
traditional sign of a tavern, made using colored stones from the Brintors. 
The streets of Arien plaza are to the south.

<359hp 188m 190mv>

The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut
above the typical tavern, with the occasional painting adorning the walls,
and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  An exit lies to a hallway to
the east, and the bar is further west of here.

[Exits: north east south]

<359hp 188m 182mv> 
s
The Western Arien Plaza
  The Arien Plaza comes to an end here as it approaches the western gate of
Earendam.  Travelers and merchants head out through this gate onto the
Arien road, bringing goods to and from the lands to the west.  Set in the
northwestern portion of the city, this plaza is a square ringed on all
sides by the buildings and walls of New Earendam.  Paved with cobblestones
long worn smooth by the feet of travelers entering the city from the Arien
road, the center of the square lies eastward, where an ornate fountain
serves as a resting place for the main body of the populace in the immediate
area.  Shops line the northern edge of the square, while southward the plaza
eventually terminates in a stone wall.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A hulking alatharya porter carries goods for a merchant.
A merchant from Var Bandor strolls through the plaza.

<359hp 188m 188mv> 
note
[  0] Iandir: Welcome to Avendar
Tue Oct 29 22:51:07 2024
To: all immortal
Welcome to Avendar.  Whether this is your first character or the latest
of many, we appreciate you joining us.  If you have not played in some time,
be aware that there have been significant changes to classes, lineages,
skills, spells, items, encounters, and the world in general.  Many things
may be very different from how you remember them being.  

A summary of some of our recent updates:

- Most restrictions on possible lineage and class combinations have been
removed.  

- Stats, HP, and MP may no longer be trained.  HP/MP is now based on class
alone.  Stats will automatically advance as you level.  Please see HELP
STATS for more information.  

- Skill practicing is now decoupled from stats.  Most skills will now always
practice to 75%.  

- All stats have been rebalanced and what each stat does has changed. 
Please see HELP STATS for more information.  

- All bonuses and penalties to experience gain based on resonance/aura have
been removed.  This will still affect your own aura.  

- Girikha is dead, slain by adventurers by command of Iandir.  

- The saint/demigod Calaera no longer acts as an independent deity, and no
longer issues sigils or god touches.  

- The sacrifice and god touch mechanics have both been significantly
revised.  Please see HELP SACRIFICE and HELP GOD TOUCH for more information.

- The Guardians of Law are no longer a Great House.  - The role of Great
Houses and their criteria for joining has changed.  Please see HELP GREAT
HOUSE for more information.  

- Kankoran are in the process of being removed entirely from Avendar and
their existence retconned.  Kankoran NPCs still exist for now as do
references to kankoran, but all are in the process of being rewritten, and
new kankoran PCs may not be made.  Please see HELP KANKORAN for more
information.  

- Most lineages have been given significant expansions to their histories,
cultures, and/or aesthetics.  Please see the relevant help files and the
wiki for more information.  

Updates to our in-game help files to accurately represent added skills,
spells, and other mechanical changes are in progress.  In the mean time,
please check out our website or direct any questions to our Discord.  

Thanks for playing with us, we hope you have fun.

The Earendam Docks
  A wide wooden docks has been erected just to the north of the River

move immediately.  An occasional raft or barge can be seen on the river,

Outside the Northern Gatehouse
  The towering gates of Var Bandor rise to the south.  Huge, heavy wooden
doors reinforced with iron bars, the gates are maintained rigorously.  The
walls to the east and west are solid stone, with murder slits.  To the
north, the river Dantaron splits into two mighty forks which flow by Var
Bandor on either side.

Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.

<359hp 188m 198mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

Ilrin Street
  A wide street composed of black stones and carefully-arranged curbs,

prohibited.  The Var Bandor Center Square is to the north.

The Forest Path

east and west, breaks in the thick treeline are visible.

Before Chanisal Monastery
  The footpath comes to an end here, just before the wooden gates of the
monastery.  The buildings are tall, but below the mighty Nendorin canopy;
the proper size and sprawl of the complex is not apparent further west.  The
trees give way to long, thick grasses which encroach on the smooth cobbles
of the path and peek between some of its stones.  Wooden posts sporting
bronze enclosures are sparse, but provide enough light to make the way
visible even at night.  The air is fragrant and wild, the scents of the
forest and its creatures drifting upon it.  To the north is the entrance to
the monastery complex, while the uneven path continues west.

At the Wooden Gates
  Twelve feet tall and worked from Nendorin oak, the complex's entrance
maintains a careful balance between secure and welcoming.  The stone of the
monastery's central enclosure rises a few feet above the top of the
woodwork, its interior wildlife pushing at is boundaries.  From here, the
high, sloped roof rises prominently, revealing the monastery's split
eastern-western design.  The forest air is sweet, the faint breath of lilies
in its rich undertone.  A dirt path leads south back toward the forest,
while the monastery's famous sanctuary lies to the north.

An Enclosed Sanctuary
  The beginning of the monastery's miraculous sanctuary is a half-circle of
cobbled stones, giving definitive close to the road which led up to it. 
Here, the wondrous variety of the Qali clan's druidic mastery is more than
apparent; tall pines, spidery lowland trees, elms, beeches, and wide
goldenrain leaves are all visible.  The earth underfoot is dark and fertile,
partially concealed by a stretch of white rose bushes.  Stones bearing
ancient druidic markings are dug into the soil here and there, bending the
local climate to what suits the diverse array of flora.  The air is a wash
of scents, from stone, to moss, to salt, to swamp mist, to blooming flowers.
A meandering cobbled path leads through the wildlife, directing visitors
north, while smaller bare stretches lead east and west.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A Qali druid reaches out, small plants growing beneath the palm of her hand.

with reverence throughout the sanctuary and the garden in silence.  Wearing
monastery robes, it is likely that her training is in the hands of Eliqali,

The Sanctuary's Heart
  At the heart of the monastery is a bounteous grove, cultivated by both
druidic ritual and centuries of meticulous tending.  The plot is roughly
circular, the earth richer and darker than one would expect for the region. 
From it grow a thick cover of ever-blooming white lilies, split only by a
meandering cobbled footpath.  In the grove's center, a spectacular living
sculpture depicts a young caladaran girl, shaped entirely from carefully
bent saplings.  The air is alive with fragrance, capturing some essential,
foreign spirit in its headiness.  The sanctuary continues in all directions,
halting only when it reaches the walls of its stone enclosure.  

[Exits: north east south west]
Eliqali, keeper of the sanctuary, pads silently amongst the leaves.

<359hp 188m 181mv> 
l 2.
A lean, brown-skinned ethron woman, Eliqali both adds new flora to the
monastic sanctuary, and maintains what already grows there.  With vivid
green eyes and wild, olive hair, she is both talented and striking; her
mastery of druidic runestones is rivaled only by Avendar's most famous
hierophants.  A daughter of clan Qali, she was born and raised on monastery
grounds, training with the elder matrons as a teenager and traveling as a
young adult.  After returning home, she vowed to the All-Mother that she
would spend her life here, making certain that the wondrous legacy of her
ancestors would endure.  
Eliqali is in excellent condition.

An Enclosed Sanctuary
  Just south of the local vegetable garden is the monastery's miraculous
sanctuary.  Here, the wondrous variety of the Qali clan's druidic mastery is
more than apparent; tall pines, spidery lowland trees, elms, beeches, and
wide goldenrain leaves are all visible.  The earth underfoot is dark and
fertile, partially concealed by a patch of bright yellow daffodils.  Stones
bearing ancient druidic markings are dug into the soil here and there,
bending the local climate to what suits the diverse array of flora.  The air
is a wash of scents, from stone, to moss, to salt, to swamp mist, to
blooming flowers.  A meandering cobbled path leads through the wildlife,
directing visitors south, while smaller bare stretches lead east and west.

The Monastery Garden
  To the north of the sanctuary's enclosure is the local garden, which
provides a small portion of the monks' food.  Vegetables are planted in
orderly rows, the dark earth fertile enough for an impressive yield relative
to their size.  The footprints of residents mark out paths between the rows,
and a small surrounding fence keeps forest denizens mostly at bay.  Unlike
other sections of the monastery exterior, there are no lanterns along the
roof's edge.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the heady
aroma of tilled earth.  To the east, the garden continues, the stone wall of
the sanctuary opening up to the south.

At the Stone Well
  In the northwest corner of the local garden, the orderly rows slow to a
halt.  The earth here is covered by lush, pleasant grass, much of it padded
down from the passage of feet.  The natural spring which serves the
monastery is found here; the source of local water for monks and visitors. 
A single, bronze lantern hangs over the well, providing just enough light to
locate it in the dark.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the
heady aroma of tilled earth, as well as the smell of water on stone.  A dirt
path leads westward behind the monastery, while the garden proper waits to
the east and south.

enough for an impressive yield relative to their size.  The footprints of
residents mark out paths between the rows, and a small surrounding fence

exterior, there are no lanterns along the roof's edge.  The air carries the
mild sting of fertilizer and the heady aroma of tilled earth.  The

A Lush Green Yard
  Outside of the monastery ward, a grassy strip has been cleared for
patients to enjoy.  The grass is long and lush, spotted with the occasional
dandelions, and small shrubs hunch beneath the monastery's large windows. 
Here, the scents of the forest follow the wind through its branches at the
yard's edges, Nendor's wild encroachment becomes impassable.  A small line
of hanging lanterns hang from the edge of the ward's sloped roof, keeping
the yard lit at night.  The verdant expanse continues to the east, while the
local monastic garden opens up to the west.

<370hp 193m 212mv> 
l 2.
One of the more enigmatic members of the Lijenin Order, Dachati is
wizened caladaran woman.  Birch-white and speckled in brown, her eyes are a
hazy, distant blue, and her hair is brittle like dried tinder.  A
spiritmaster hailing from the war-torn Rirro Jagka, she made the long and
dangerous journey to Nendor first in the dreamworld, and then in the real
one.  Although she has never made expressly clear what directed her to this
place, she occasionally speaks of a blossoming rope of lilies that tethers
her to the waking world.  Her vast intelligence and curious fugue made her
initiation into the Order a foregone conclusion, bridging the realities of
mind, spirit, and body.  
Dachati is in excellent condition.

A Small Dirt Path
  Behind the monastery is a dirt path leading from the Qali forum to the
monastery's well.  A shortcut for thirsty petitioners, the earth is packed
hard from many generations of footsteps.  Like the rest of the untended
space behind the complex, lush grass grows wild, closing in around the
much-used path and hugging the edge of the building's exterior.  Lanterns
hang from the edge of the monastery's sloped roof, providing meager light
after dark.  The air here is clear and wild, having only a touch of the
acrid fertilizer that is used in the nearby garden.  The dirt path leads to
the east, while two stone steps lead up to the doorway into the Qali forum. 

[Exits: east (south)]

<370hp 193m 204mv> You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Qali Forum
  On the northern side of the monastery's western section is the Qali
forum, where both children and the devoted are taught.  Named for the ethron
clan which helped found the monastery, it is the most decorated interior
within it the walls are painted in simple, but effective murals of the
complex's beginnings.  Circles of mats comfort students as they sit, as well
as bring a bit of additional warmth to the chamber.  North-facing windows
light the forum as a whole, while a bronze candelabra hangs above this
section, supporting instruction after dark.  The smell of smoke and wax
tinge the air, although it remains clear enough not to be distracting.  A
door to the north leads out to the monastery rear, while the forum continues
to the south and west.  

[Exits: north south west]

The Qali Forum
  On the northern side of the monastery's western section is the Qali
forum, where both children and the devoted are taught.  Named for the ethron
clan which helped found the monastery, it is the most decorated interior
within it the walls are painted in simple, but effective murals of the
complex's beginnings.  Here, a circle of mats comforts children as they sit;
at its center, a circular hole in the floor boards exposes the dark,
Nendorin earth.  North-facing windows light the forum as a whole, while a
bronze candelabra hangs above this section, supporting instruction after
dark.  The smell of smoke and wax tinge the air, although it remains clear
enough not to be distracting.  To the east and south, the forum continues.

Taqashe Ana-Qali, one of the monastery's teachers and sages, is an
elegant ethron woman.  Her skin is pale green, and her face is pleasantly
exotic; the natural curl of her rich, green hair only adds to her unusual
appeal.  After being orphaned during a Scourge attack on Var Bandor, a Qali

mysteries of Earth and Spirit, and upon maturity, was ritually initiated
into her foster mother's clan.  Now, she spends her days looking after local
children, clever with both cantrip and lesson.

The Western Vestibule
  On the west side of the sanctuary's druidic enclosure is a small
vestibule, which serves as a gateway to this side of the monastery.  Various
hooks for coats and cloaks line the open wall space, taking the place of any
meaningful decoration.  The room itself is built from Nendorin timber, with
heavy wooden beams supporting the ceiling and treated planks composing the
rest.  On clear days, light filters through four uneven glass skylights;
otherwise, it is lit by a central hanging bronze lantern.  The sweet, exotic
scents of the sanctuary drift into the room, mixed with the pleasant aroma
of cooking.  The communal dining hall lies to the west, while the Qali forum
is to the north.  A small hallway leads south.

A Cramped Hallway
  This small spur off of the western section of the monastery is cramped,
barely wide enough for two people to pass each other in it.  Despite leading
to the complex's earthen cellar, the well-worn floor is swept meticulously
clear of dirt or debris.  The ceiling here is a bit low, suggesting that
this hall was a late addition to the construction.  Two small windows, set
at about shoulder level, provide light for the room during the day, while a
bronze lantern in the east corner handles the rest.  The scent of earth is
stronger here, and the air is cooler than elsewhere in the monastery.  The
western vestibule lies to the north, while the spur continues westward to a
stairwell.

  The small spur off of the western section of the monastery is cramped,

A Well-Stocked Dry Storage
  Connected to the monastery kitchen is a storage area, meant to hold dry
or immediate supplies for its cook.  Jars of preserved fruit, strings of
hanging herbs, sacks of flour, and other necessities are all present within
its confines.  The northern wall has the largest shelves, which stand about
eight feet high; the southern counterpart is about four, allowing room for a
blurry glass window above it.  The floor is scuffed but swept clear, as this
is the most direct route from the kitchen to the monastery cellar.  While
the scent of meals lingers in the air, the bite of dry herbs and the dull
tone of flour temper it.  To the west is the kitchen proper, while the
cramped stairwell to the underground lies east.

An Ancient Cellar
  The cellar is by far the oldest part of the monastery, dating back to its
inception at the close of the War of Night.  It is dank, the walls cut from
the dark earth of Nendor and supported by stone and ancient, treated timber.
The floor is bare, packed dirt, save the uncharacteristic stone steps that
lead down to it.  Here, the locals store whatever needs to remain cool;
large barrels of beer from Eril, crates of extra clothing, and stores of wax
and lamp oil included.  The air is cool, close, and heavy, smelling of rich
earth and timeless stone.  The cellar continues north, while the monastery
proper waits above.

An Ancient Cellar
  The cellar is by far the oldest part of the monastery, dating back to its
inception at the close of the War of Night.  It is dank, the walls cut from
the dark earth of Nendor and supported by stone and ancient, treated timber.
The floor is bare, packed dirt, hard and merciless underfoot.  Here, the
locals store whatever needs to remain cool; large barrels of beer from Eril,
crates of extra clothing, and stores of wax and lamp oil included.  The air
is cool, close, and heavy, smelling of rich earth and timeless stone.  The
cellar continues east and west, while the stairwell to the surface is to the
south.

The Passage to the Cellar
  The small spur off of the western section of the monastery is cramped,
barely wide enough for two people to pass each other in it.  Despite leading
to the complex's earthen cellar, the well-worn floor is swept meticulously
clear of dirt or debris.  The ceiling here is a bit low, suggesting that
this hall was a late addition to the construction.  One small window, set at
about shoulder level, provides light for the hall during the day, and
ambient light serves during the rest.  The scent of earth is strong here,
venting up from the stairwell downward, and carries with it a noticeable
chill.  The spur continues to the east, and transitions into a dry storage
for the kitchen to the west.

A Well-Stocked Dry Storage
  Connected to the monastery kitchen is a storage area, meant to hold dry
or immediate supplies for its cook.  Jars of preserved fruit, strings of
hanging herbs, sacks of flour, and other necessities are all present within
its confines.  The northern wall has the largest shelves, which stand about
eight feet high; the southern counterpart is about four, allowing room for a
blurry glass window above it.  The floor is scuffed but swept clear, as this
is the most direct route from the kitchen to the monastery cellar.  While
the scent of meals lingers in the air, the bite of dry herbs and the dull
tone of flour temper it.  To the west is the kitchen proper, while the
cramped stairwell to the underground lies east.

The Monastery Kitchen
  On the southern side of the monastery's dining hall is the kitchen,
tasked with preparing food for both residents and visitors.  The walls are
unpainted wood, instead favoring a pleasant varnish; this is not echoed in

the hearth is ever-present, masked only by the flavorful aromas of meals,

A Communal Dining Hall
  The largest and most active area of the monastery's western side is the
dining room.  It serves all of the monks and devoted who live on the complex

benches line the area, encouraging community between those who eat here.

prepared, or was for the last meal.  To the south is the monastery's

The Side Entrance to the Monastery

A Well-Trod Path
  This well-trod path is covered by the canopy of Nendor, crowding out much
of its natural light.  A cobble or two is worked into the hard earth, as if
the path was once fully paved; however, either by removal or wear, many of
them are no longer present.  The forest itself looms overhead, thick trees
and tangled underbrush ensure that travelers tread more or less the same
path every trip.  A few standing lamp posts provide meager light at night,
their metalwork and treated wood showing many decades of wear.  The air here
is clear and wild, drawn through the branches and shrubbery from within the
forest itself.  The path continues to the west, while the cobbles grow more
common as the trees break off to the east.

<381hp 196m 230mv> Inside the Southern Gatehouse
  The southern gatehouse of Var Bandor is an elaborate affair,
well-maintained and proper.  A close watch is kept on the kind of traveler
allowed to enter the finest districts of the city, and a roster of those
banned from the area is kept nearby.  The immense granite walls rise to
either side of the gates, and to the south, the outskirts of Var Bandor run
into a thickly wooded area.  North, Ilrin Street leads into the heart of the
city.

n
Ilrin Street
  A wide street composed of black stones and carefully-arranged curbs,
Ilrin Street runs the length of southern Var Bandor, winding among the
gloriously rich houses of the merchants and the eccentrically constructed
towers of the scholars.  Here and there, baskets of flowers hang from the
sides of buildings, and hired servants tend to shaped shrubs.  The streets
in the southern part of town are swept clean, and all animal traffic is
prohibited.  To the east, Arcanos Street leads to the scholars' towers.

sides of buildings, and hired servants tend to shaped shrubs.  The streets
in the southern part of town are swept clean, and all animal traffic is
prohibited.  To the west is the guild of watchers, while Naidji Alley lies to
the east.

Ilrin Street
  A wide street composed of black stones and carefully-arranged curbs,
Ilrin Street runs the length of southern Var Bandor, winding among the
gloriously rich houses of the merchants and the eccentrically constructed
towers of the scholars.  Here and there, baskets of flowers hang from the
sides of buildings, and hired servants tend to shaped shrubs.  The streets

n
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

Leather Shop
  A thin layer of dust is visible throughout this building, which clearly
was once a leather shop of some sort.  Bare hooks line the walls, where once
merchandise must have hung.  An old counter sits near the back, emptied and

A Brightly-Lit Shop
  A fortune's worth of glass fronts this shop, its meticulous frosting
obscuring the dreary cobbles of Iron Street.  A fireplace set into the side
wall wards off the damp and fills the room with a fragrant pine scent;
enough to mute the acrid tinge from the tannery next door.  Thin stone
columns support the raised ceiling, making this building taller than those
around it.  Above, a massive and opulent golden chandelier lights the shop,
its smoke and those of the steel sconces about the room darkening the roof's
wooden beams.  At the back of the store is a low, wide counter, providing an
easy work surface for final clothing alterations.  

[Exits: north]
A plump, middle-aged woman makes alterations to a dress on the counter.

Iron Street Foundry
  Huge cauldrons of molten iron are the most numerous item in the foundry. 
Some are being heated over huge furnaces, just turning the yellow-orange
color of heated ore while others are being lifted over molds and tilted to
dump their contents into cast molds.  Hissing and the ringing of metal on
metal assault your ears as finished casts are being thrust into barrels of
salt water or oil, depending on the finish wanted for the item or if a
worker is putting some finishing touches on a cast with his hammer.  You can
exit back to Iron street to the north.  

[Exits: north]

The Blacksmith
  It's thrice hotter inside the blacksmith's than it is on the street.  A
thick curtain of smoke hangs in the air, and metal shavings cover the floor.
Three large, hot furnaces are built into the far wall, creating the immense
heat of this room.  An anvil and hammer sit off near the far corner, along
with a barrel full of cool water.  A large pile of scrap metal sits off in
one corner, waiting to be molded into something.  North leads from the near
unbearable temperature back unto the street.

The Wheelwright's
  The room is filled with a thick dust created from wood-shavings, making
it hard to breathe.  Large logs are lined up against the far wall, waiting
to be cut into wheels and spokes.  A large oven takes up the west wall, made
to smoke the wood boards so they would bend into shape.  A few saws and
other instruments for carving hang against the wall waiting to be used. 
Below them are a few half finished wheels, cut crudely.  Sawdust and hay
blanket the floor, causing dust to billow up and fill the room with every
motion.  If you wished to leave, your only option is to return to the street
to the north.  

[Exits: north]
     A huge, wooden wheel is here lying broken on the ground.
Terintbanch is here bending pieces of metal and wood to his will.
Terintbanch Plun says, 'Greetings, Sir.'

n
Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.  

[Exits: north south]
A soldier of the Var Bandor Guard watches the gatehouse.

<381hp 196m 240mv> 
Outside the Northern Gatehouse
  The towering gates of Var Bandor rise to the south.  Huge, heavy wooden
doors reinforced with iron bars, the gates are maintained rigorously.  The
walls to the east and west are solid stone, with murder slits.  To the
north, the river Dantaron splits into two mighty forks which flow by Var
Bandor on either side.

  You stand outside the north wall of Var Bandor.  In the distance to the

on either side.  The ground here is muddy and level, with little grass
growing. Behind you to the south, the stone wall of the city overshadows

A Ferry Station
  The waters of the Dantaron River flow placidly to the north, a muddy
brown barrier to merchants, carts, and foot travelers.  A small wooden dock
has been erected at the water's edge, and several large ferries run by

The Dantaron River
  The winding Dantaron River turns to the east, flowing by the city of Var
Bandor.  The placid, muddy waters ripple gently as they run their course,
eventually leading to Earendam eastward.  The stone walls of Var Bandor
tower menacingly to the south, and north and south of the river ferry
stations have been set up.

and merchants trading with the mountain outposts to the north, but in recent
years the road has fallen into disuse, and is no longer actively maintained.
The Earendam Road leads east and west through the grasslands.

other direction of travel is southward, where the road continues along the
same level of elevation.  Cutting through the area is a chill wind, blowing
down from the ice capped mountains nearby.

The End of the Vorinden Road
  The Vorinden road comes to an end here, halting before the walls and iron

The Iron Gates of Kor Thrandir
  A large iron gate stands open, allowing passage by the high stone walls
of Kor Thrandir.  A dark blue flag above the gate flaps in the mountain
wind, bearing the Lord Protector's iron cross.  The rugged mountain road is
swept clear, rising into paved cobblestone just outside the town walls.  A
series of pikes stand along the outer wall, the grinning, eyeless skulls of
shuddeni stuck upon them.  From here, the great keep of Kor Thrandir is
visible in the distance to the east.  Additional guard posts are just inside
the walls to the north and south.  The Vorinden Road lies to the west.

The Beginning of Kalyius Way
  Inside the gates, a paved cobblestone street leads through the town of
Kor Thrandir.  Known as Kalyius Way, it takes its name from the famed War of
Night general.  The road itself is surprisingly clean, likely due to the
mountain wind catching the dirt and debris from both caravans and the boots
of travelers.  Stone buildings with high, sloped roofs line the street,
their heavy wooden doors keeping out the cool, fickle breeze.  What plants
are visible are mostly squat shrubs that grow stubbornly in the rocky soil. 
A sign on the building to the north marks it as the Pearl Cross.  The iron
gates are to the west, while the cobblestones continue east.

Alliance Square
  In the center of the western portion of Kor Thrandir is Alliance Square,
named so in honor of the victorious surface forces.  A large fountain stands
in the middle of it, giving it a more indulgent look than much of the
spartan keep.  A series of wooden benches sit around the fountain, providing
citizens and travelers alike with a place to rest.  The mountain air is
clear and fresh as it blows between the town's buildings.  To the north is
the Inn of the Northern Lights, which also serves as the town bar.  Cobbled
roads lead east, south, and west.

An Entrance to the High Tower
  A wide, hard-packed dirt path circles the keep of Kor Thrandir,
connecting the houses and shops to the training areas, temple, and
infirmary.  The grass grows wild on the outside of the trail, smattered with
tiny white wildflowers.  The looming presence of the keep reaches skyward to
the east, its ancient stones looking dreadfully imposing.  The mountain wind
whips about the tower, sending the grasses into a sudden wave.  The path
continues north and south, while to the west, a paved road leads to the
town's shops and homes.  To the east, a large door leads into the keep
itself.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<402hp 204m 172mv>

You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
The Gallery of Heroes
  The ceiling for the base floor of the tower extends nearly twenty feet
into the air, supported by dark stone columns.  Orbs of smokeless orange
light, high above, are mounted upon the pillars, casting their light
throughout the floor.  Set into the nearby pillar is an oil painting of
General Kalyius, leader of the Army of the Golden Hand.  A golden plaque
beneath it describes his personal heroism.  The tile floor is well-swept,
and the air is still with reverence.  Heavy wooden doors lead both to the
north and south.  The Gallery of Heroes continues to the east, while the
exit to the tower is west.

The Monument to the Lord Protector
  At the center of the base floor of the tower is a huge bronze monument. 
Standing over ten feet tall, it depicts an enormous human warrior plunging a
sword into a fallen shuddeni's chest.  The heavy stone pillars form a ring,
encircling the monument.  Mounted orbs of smokeless orange light are placed
high upon the pillars, bathing the statue in a permanent glow.  The tile
floor is well-swept, and the air is still with reverence.  The four halls
which compose the Gallery of Heroes all lead to this monument, one to the
north, east, south, and west.

The Southern Path
  Large, wooden barricades line the southern path, ensuring that the
training areas for the Kor Thrandian soldiers and archers remain both

swordsmen, and scholars, with only the few stubborn weeds that spring up at

entrance to the training grounds of Kor Thrandir.  Grunts of exertion, as

<403hp 204m 187mv> 
l 2.
A savage looking man with sunbeaten skin, Velitius is one of Kor
Thrandir's primary field marshals.  He is tall, muscular, and tough, his
head shaved and face reddened from exposure.  He has a prominent scar over
one eye, which he received in the defense of the keep during the Eyeblight
War.  He has a notorious reputation for his rigorous exercise regimen and
no-excuses attitude, which made him a favorite of the Lord Protector.  He
spends most of his days and nights on the training grounds, overseeing young
soldiers as they hone their skills.  
Lieutenant Commander Velitius is in excellent condition.

The Training Grounds
  The training grounds of Kor Thrandir are a hodgepodge of activity,
mottled grass, and hard-packed dirt.  The shouts of battle and the clash of
wooden weapons split the air, and the heavy scent of sweat drifts by on the
mountain wind.  There are no trees within the training ground, making it a
thoroughly open expanse enclosed by heavy wooden barricades.  A rise in the
southwest corner of the field provides an overview for the overseeing
officer, while pairs of soldiers spar on the grassy turf below it.  To the
north and east, the training grounds continue, while a small hill slopes up
to the west.

  An open wooden gate serves as the entrance to the training grounds of Kor
Thrandir.  The shouts of battle and the clash of wooden weapons split the

<403hp 204m 235mv> 
The Southern Path
  The barricades which line the southern path open up here, allowing
entrance to the training grounds of Kor Thrandir.  Grunts of exertion, as
well as the clack of practice weapons and the snap of bowstrings, form a low
din which persists at nearly all hours.  The scents of practice, as well as
those of the trampled grasses and mountain wind, mix alternatingly with the
passing of the breeze.  To the west, young Thrandian soldiers practice their
martial skills, while to the east is the archery range.  The path continues
south into a cobbled courtyard, and north toward the keep.  

[Exits: north east south west]

The Southern Path

training areas for the Kor Thrandian soldiers and archers remain both

An Entrance to the High Tower
  A wide, hard-packed dirt path circles the keep of Kor Thrandir,
connecting the houses and shops to the training areas, temple, and
infirmary.  The grass grows wild on the outside of the trail, smattered with
tiny white wildflowers.  The looming presence of the keep reaches skyward to
the north, its ancient stones looking dreadfully imposing.  The mountain
wind whips about the tower, sending the grasses into a sudden wave.  The
path continues east and west, while to the south, another path branches off
to the practice fields and schools.  To the north, a large door leads into
the keep itself.

help endurance
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Endurance (Skill)                                                |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  0 mana

Syntax: Automatic

Despite their vast diversity of training between the ranger, fighter,
barbarian, and watcher classes, all of them are used to bouts of hard or
speedy travel.  With the endurance skill, the user will have a heightened
regeneration rate of movement points.  

For the trait, please see help ENDURANCE-TRAIT.

The Gallery of Heroes
  The ceiling for the base floor of the tower extends nearly twenty feet
into the air, supported by dark stone columns.  Orbs of smokeless orange
light, high above, are mounted upon the pillars, casting their light
throughout the floor.  Set into the nearby pillar is an oil painting of
Rakinal, the kankoran chieftain during the War of Night.  A golden plaque
beneath it describes his contribution to the war effort.  The tile floor is
well-swept, and the air is still with reverence.  Heavy wooden doors lead
both to the east and west.  The Gallery of Heroes continues to the north,
while the exit to the tower is south.

The Monument to the Lord Protector
  At the center of the base floor of the tower is a huge bronze monument.

sword into a fallen shuddeni's chest.  The heavy stone pillars form a ring,

floor is well-swept, and the air is still with reverence.  The four halls
which compose the Gallery of Heroes all lead to this monument, one to the

<403hp 204m 249mv> 
The End of Kalyius Way
  This paved cobblestone street connects the Kor Thrandian gates to the
fortified central tower.  Kalyius Way is surprisingly clean, likely due to
the mountain wind catching the dirt and debris from both caravans and the
boots of travelers.  Stone buildings with high, sloped roofs line the
street, their heavy wooden doors keeping out the cool, fickle breeze.  What
plants are visible are mostly squat shrubs that grow stubbornly in the rocky
soil.  To the north is the local bank branch, the Soldier's Wallet.  To the
east, the cobbled road gives way to a path of hard-packed dirt.  The massive
keep of Kor Thrandir towers high above.

  This paved cobblestone street connects the Kor Thrandian gates to the

An Entrance to the High Tower
  A wide, hard-packed dirt path circles the keep of Kor Thrandir,
connecting the houses and shops to the training areas, temple, and
infirmary.  The grass grows wild on the outside of the trail, smattered with
tiny white wildflowers.  The looming presence of the keep reaches skyward to
the east, its ancient stones looking dreadfully imposing.  The mountain wind
whips about the tower, sending the grasses into a sudden wave.  The path
continues north and south, while to the west, a paved road leads to the
town's shops and homes.  To the east, a large door leads into the keep
itself.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<403hp 204m 245mv> 
e
The Gallery of Heroes
  The ceiling for the base floor of the tower extends nearly twenty feet
into the air, supported by dark stone columns.  Orbs of smokeless orange
light, high above, are mounted upon the pillars, casting their light
throughout the floor.  Set into the nearby pillar is an oil painting of
General Kalyius, leader of the Army of the Golden Hand.  A golden plaque
beneath it describes his personal heroism.  The tile floor is well-swept,
and the air is still with reverence.  Heavy wooden doors lead both to the
north and south.  The Gallery of Heroes continues to the east, while the
exit to the tower is west.

<403hp 204m 243mv> 
e
The Monument to the Lord Protector
  At the center of the base floor of the tower is a huge bronze monument. 
Standing over ten feet tall, it depicts an enormous human warrior plunging a
sword into a fallen shuddeni's chest.  The heavy stone pillars form a ring,
encircling the monument.  Mounted orbs of smokeless orange light are placed
high upon the pillars, bathing the statue in a permanent glow.  The tile
floor is well-swept, and the air is still with reverence.  The four halls
which compose the Gallery of Heroes all lead to this monument, one to the
north, east, south, and west.

The End of the Northern Path
  At the end of the northern path, it diverges into two smaller trails, one
leading to the barracks and the other leading to the mess hall.  Both
structures are made of imposing local stone, and only bear the slightest
resemblance to the grand military buildings typical of the Earendam river
valley.  The split in the path is shaded by the unusual presence of large
trees to the north, the mountain breeze filtering through them.  The scents
of mess hall food linger in the air, and the loud sounds of soldiers at rest
form a near-constant din.

<403hp 204m 235mv> 
l druid
About five feet tall, Rhuidar Neloneus is a famous ethron druid of the
Brintor Mountains.  He has long, brown hair and a similarly long beard,
framing his pleasant but unremarkable face.  His skin is a pale green, and
shows the weathering of the elevation's cold wind.  Born in the mountains,
he earned a notable reputation by foiling the plans of shuddeni slavers. 
His presence was welcomed by Lord Protector Malyn, who hailed him as a hero,
and he has since remained within Kor Thrandir.  He spends much of his time
tending his garden, stirring life amidst the stones.  
Rhuidar Neloneus is in excellent condition.

Rhuidar Neloneus is using:
<worn on hands> a pair of gloves woven from blades of grass
<two-handed>    a gnarled oaken staff

A White Infirmary
  The military infirmary is a single, spacious room filled with a series of
bunk beds.  The stone walls are paneled with wood and painted a calming
white, with various icons of the iron cross hung as decorations.  Along the
south wall, a counter provides a workspace for the attending scholar, and a
rack of shelves provides fresh bandages, salves, and other supplies.  The
air is sterile, tinged with the sharp scent of herbal medicine.  Three
hanging white globes provide ample light for the infirmary.  The eastern
door leads outside, to a hard-packed dirt path.
