Alliance Square
  In the center of the western portion of Kor Thrandir is Alliance Square,
named so in honor of the victorious surface forces.  A large fountain stands
in the middle of it, giving it a more indulgent look than much of the
spartan keep.  A series of wooden benches sit around the fountain, providing
citizens and travelers alike with a place to rest.  The mountain air is
clear and fresh as it blows between the town's buildings.  To the north is
the Inn of the Northern Lights, which also serves as the town bar.  Cobbled
roads lead east, south, and west.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A carved stone fountain provides a constant stream of cold water.

<403hp 204m 176mv> 
l chadrassa
A tall caladaran wearing soft clothes, the wanderer Chadrassa is one of
the most famed Water mages in all of Avendar.  Despite his hermetic
lifestyle, he famously took on the mantle of training advanced water
scholars when the dread magic of Gyel'Xan spirited away the Titans of Castle
Nathli.  He has since become more exclusive with his tutelage, taking on
only those who devote themselves to the Wintertide.  He travels the northern
plains alone, enjoying both his solitude and the local wildlife he keeps as
company.  
Chadrassa is in excellent condition.

<412hp 211m 191mv> 
The North Gates of Earendam
  Earendam's north gates are forged from black iron, built between the
stone walls of the city.  Reinforced by stout iron bars, the gates are built
thick, for increased security.  Outside the gates lie the expanse of the
northern grasslands, across which runs the Earendam road, which leads all
the way to the Brintors.  Inside, Tyril Square marks the beginning of
Earendam proper.  

[Exits: north south]
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.

<412hp 211m 190mv> 
s
North of Tyril Square
  The north part of Tyril square lies very near the gates of Earendam,
which lie to the north.  Past the gates are grasslands, and eventually the
Brintor mountains, which provide most of the source of Earendam's mineral
wealth and its building materials.  The gate is mainly used by Brintorean
miners, traders, or the occasionally diplomatic party from Kor Thrandir. 
East and west, the corners of the square end in arched buildings, while a
central fountain dominates the square to the south.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<412hp 211m 189mv> 
s
Center of Tyril Square
  The center of Tyril square is dominated by a marble statue, serving as
the centerpiece for a concentric series of fountains.  Serving as the
junction for travel between Earendam's north gate, the mercantile quarter,
the artisan's district, and the occasional nobleman from Old Earendam across
the Dantaron, the square is nevertheless well-maintained, and covered with a
glazed brown cobblestone of Brintorean stone.  The main throughfares of the
square are Frinian Way, which intersects the square in the east and picks
up again in the west, and Tyril Way, which opens onto the square to the
south.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A muscular protector is loitering here, surveying the area casually.

e
<412hp 211m 188mv> 
East of Tyril Square
  The east of Tyril Square is covered with a smooth cobblestone of glazed
brown bricks.  Near the north gate of Earendam, Tyril Square is filled with
the traffic of artisans and scholars who inhabit this part of the city.  The
center of the square is west, where a marble statue rises out of the silver
base of a large fountain.  South and north are the edges of the square,
where scholars have set up shop to ply the wares of some of Avendar's most
famous magicks.  To the east Frinian Way heads into the heart of the
artisan's quarter, where scholars and craftsman come to learn and ply their
trade.  

[Exits: north east south west]
Corporal Landilus patrols the city, watchful for any sign of trouble.

<412hp 211m 187mv> 
s
Southeast of Tyril Square
  The southeast corner of Tyril Square is a popular gathering spot for
scholars, nestled as it is between the sides of two of the city's most
renowned storehouses of arcana.  Both buildings lie to the south and east,
and both are constructed in the manner of the grand Republican style --
Brintor marble stairs lead up above street level to pass through ornate
columns into the respective stores, both trying their best to dominate their
immediate environs.  The square opens in streets both north and west of
here, while a central fountain lies northwest.  An ornate marble marker with
inscribed writing here lies between the two shops, identifying features of
each.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<412hp 211m 186mv> 
e
Ilyath's Scrolls
  Ilyath's Scrolls is constructed in the classical Republican style of
Earendam, from the domed ceiling to the intricately carved friezes above the
columns which circle the room.  Between each of the pillars is a glass case,
behind which rest the scrolls Illyath has made available.  Exits lead down
stairs to the west and north.  

[Exits: north west]
Ilyath strolls about the shop, offering his scrolls.

where scholars have set up shop to ply the wares of some of Avendar's most
famous magicks.  To the east Frinian Way heads into the heart of the
artisan's quarter, where scholars and craftsman come to learn and ply their
trade.  

[Exits: north east south west]
Corporal Landilus patrols the city, watchful for any sign of trouble.

<412hp 211m 183mv> 
Northeast of Tyril Square
  The northeast corner of Tyril Square is formed by the intersection of
Earendam's massive north wall and a squat brownstone building to the east. 
Covered with a cobblestone of glazed brown bricks, the square stretches off
south and west, heading toward the north gates of town to the west, and a

around an arched portcullis to the east, usually coming from or going to the

<412hp 211m 179mv> 
w
You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
Frinian Way
  Frinian Way is a broad but winding street which bends west and south as
it makes its way through New Earendam.  Scholars, artisans and other
craftsmen use this street, bringing their goods from the east part of the
city to service the mercantile activity in the Arien Plaza.  The street runs
flush with the northern wall of Earendam, which towers well over 
twelve feet in height.  Made from bricks shaped by earth scholars, the wall
is well maintained, and almost clashes with the much older and more scuffed
cobblestones of Frinian.  To the east of here, a gated archway leads toward
the headquarters of the Company of the Jackal, one of the groups of
chartered templars which patrol the area north of Earendam proper.  

[Exits: east south west]

<423hp 212m 212mv> 
The North Gates of Earendam
  Earendam's north gates are forged from black iron, built between the
stone walls of the city.  Reinforced by stout iron bars, the gates are built
thick, for increased security.  Outside the gates lie the expanse of the
northern grasslands, across which runs the Earendam road, which leads all
the way to the Brintors.  Inside, Tyril Square marks the beginning of
Earendam proper.

The Earendam Road
  A narrow strip of stones that leads north into the grasslands, the

mountain outposts to the north.  It has since fallen into disuse, but is
still nominally maintained by Earendam.

<423hp 212m 199mv> 
The Earendam Docks
  A wide wooden docks has been erected just to the north of the River
Dantaron, flowing sluggishly to the south under the city wall.  The docks
are clear of clutter, incoming cargo being regulated closely and required to
move immediately.  An occasional raft or barge can be seen on the river,
arriving or leaving the city.  To the east, the granite walls of Earendam
tower above the dock area.  Several ladders and wooden walkways lead
downward to the water of the river itself.

border the swamps.  A light mist flows about the ground beneath you, and
lingers between the damp leaves of the ferns and mottled plantlife that
begin to grow 'round this area.  Further to the south, the ground becomes
thick with a vile brown mud as the lowlands shift into swamplands.  To the
north, the grasslands spread out.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A slender aelin floats above the murk, a sturdy bow in hand.
A large, muscular alatharya stands here, scouting the lowlands.
A sleek, black-furred panther prowls here, watching its surroundings carefully.
A tall, well-built human patroller stands alert here.
A slender aelin floats above the murk, a sturdy bow in hand.

The Earendam Docks
  A wide wooden docks has been erected just to the north of the River
Dantaron, flowing sluggishly to the south under the city wall.  The docks
are clear of clutter, incoming cargo being regulated closely and required to
move immediately.  An occasional raft or barge can be seen on the river,
arriving or leaving the city.  Several ladders and wooden walkways lead
downward to the water of the river itself.

Outside the Northern Gatehouse
  The towering gates of Var Bandor rise to the south.  Huge, heavy wooden
doors reinforced with iron bars, the gates are maintained rigorously.  The
walls to the east and west are solid stone, with murder slits.  To the
north, the river Dantaron splits into two mighty forks which flow by Var
Bandor on either side.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<447hp 221m 161mv> 
s
Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.  

[Exits: north south]
A soldier of the Var Bandor Guard watches the gatehouse.

<447hp 221m 160mv> 
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the east and west is a squalid
alley.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A young man clad in soiled clothes grins menacingly at passersby.

Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

Inside the Southern Gatehouse
  The southern gatehouse of Var Bandor is an elaborate affair,
well-maintained and proper.  A close watch is kept on the kind of traveler
allowed to enter the finest districts of the city, and a roster of those
banned from the area is kept nearby.  The immense granite walls rise to
either side of the gates, and to the south, the outskirts of Var Bandor run
into a thickly wooded area.  North, Ilrin Street leads into the heart of the
city.

<455hp 228m 174mv> Trail into the Forest
  This trail winds its way southward, through the downland south of Var
Bandor, toward the Forest of Nendor.  The edges of the dirt path are lined
with smooth stones.  Stony grassland spreads to either side beyond the chalk
stone border, and the Nendorin woods spread before you to the south.  Back
northward the walls of Var Bandor are still visible, albeit barely.

<455hp 228m 173mv> 
The Forest Path
  A thin but well worn path winds through the forest of Nendor.  Stones
inscribed with odd runic markings dot the side of the path every now and
again, standing on the border between road and forest.  Large oaks line the
path on either side, leaves casting shade upon the path below.  The singing
of birds echoes through the forest, providing a constant murmur of sound.  The
path runs south from the north, leading deeper into the forest.  To the
east and west, breaks in the thick treeline are visible.

Before Chanisal Monastery
  The footpath comes to an end here, just before the wooden gates of the
monastery.  The buildings are tall, but below the mighty Nendorin canopy;
the proper size and sprawl of the complex is not apparent further west.  The
trees give way to long, thick grasses which encroach on the smooth cobbles
of the path and peek between some of its stones.  Wooden posts sporting
bronze enclosures are sparse, but provide enough light to make the way
visible even at night.  The air is fragrant and wild, the scents of the
forest and its creatures drifting upon it.  To the north is the entrance to
the monastery complex, while the uneven path continues west.

n
An Enclosed Sanctuary
  The beginning of the monastery's miraculous sanctuary is a half-circle of
cobbled stones, giving definitive close to the road which led up to it. 
Here, the wondrous variety of the Qali clan's druidic mastery is more than
apparent; tall pines, spidery lowland trees, elms, beeches, and wide
goldenrain leaves are all visible.  The earth underfoot is dark and fertile,
partially concealed by a stretch of white rose bushes.  Stones bearing
ancient druidic markings are dug into the soil here and there, bending the
local climate to what suits the diverse array of flora.  The air is a wash
of scents, from stone, to moss, to salt, to swamp mist, to blooming flowers.
A meandering cobbled path leads through the wildlife, directing visitors
north, while smaller bare stretches lead east and west.  

[Exits: north east south west]
An ethron child plays by herself in the monastery.

<455hp 228m 161mv> 
The Sanctuary's Heart
  At the heart of the monastery is a bounteous grove, cultivated by both
druidic ritual and centuries of meticulous tending.  The plot is roughly
circular, the earth richer and darker than one would expect for the region. 
From it grow a thick cover of ever-blooming white lilies, split only by a
meandering cobbled footpath.  In the grove's center, a spectacular living
sculpture depicts a young caladaran girl, shaped entirely from carefully
bent saplings.  The air is alive with fragrance, capturing some essential,
foreign spirit in its headiness.  The sanctuary continues in all directions,
halting only when it reaches the walls of its stone enclosure.

A Cluster of Gnarled Goldenrain Trees
  In the northwest corner of the sanctuary is an spectacular display of
oddity for the region: a series of Alenshan goldenrain trees.  Large and
gnarled from their odd captivity, their roots splay out into the earth and
many branches dig at the stone.  Yet, their many golden leaves glitter

The Monastery Garden
  To the north of the sanctuary's enclosure is the local garden, which
provides a small portion of the monks' food.  Vegetables are planted in
orderly rows, the dark earth fertile enough for an impressive yield relative
to their size.  The footprints of residents mark out paths between the rows,
and a small surrounding fence keeps forest denizens mostly at bay.  Unlike
other sections of the monastery exterior, there are no lanterns along the
roof's edge.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the heady
aroma of tilled earth.  To the east, the garden continues, the stone wall of
the sanctuary opening up to the south.

patients to enjoy.  The grass is long and lush, spotted with the occasional
dandelions, and small shrubs hunch beneath the monastery's large windows. 
Here, the scents of the forest follow the wind through its branches at the
yard's edges, Nendor's wild encroachment becomes impassable.  A small line
of hanging lanterns hang from the edge of the ward's sloped roof, keeping
the yard lit at night.  The verdant expanse continues onward in both
directions, east and west.  

[Exits: east west]
(Translucent) Dachati, the Lijenin spiritmaster, lingers as if suspended in place.

l 2.
One of the more enigmatic members of the Lijenin Order, Dachati is
wizened caladaran woman.  Birch-white and speckled in brown, her eyes are a
hazy, distant blue, and her hair is brittle like dried tinder.  A
spiritmaster hailing from the war-torn Rirro Jagka, she made the long and
dangerous journey to Nendor first in the dreamworld, and then in the real
one.  Although she has never made expressly clear what directed her to this
place, she occasionally speaks of a blossoming rope of lilies that tethers
her to the waking world.  Her vast intelligence and curious fugue made her
initiation into the Order a foregone conclusion, bridging the realities of
mind, spirit, and body.  
Dachati is in excellent condition.

At the Stone Well
  In the northwest corner of the local garden, the orderly rows slow to a
halt.  The earth here is covered by lush, pleasant grass, much of it padded
down from the passage of feet.  The natural spring which serves the
monastery is found here; the source of local water for monks and visitors. 
A single, bronze lantern hangs over the well, providing just enough light to
locate it in the dark.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the
heady aroma of tilled earth, as well as the smell of water on stone.  A dirt
path leads westward behind the monastery, while the garden proper waits to
the east and south.

A Small Dirt Path
  Behind the monastery is a dirt path leading from the Qali forum to the
monastery's well.  A shortcut for thirsty petitioners, the earth is packed
hard from many generations of footsteps.  Like the rest of the untended
space behind the complex, lush grass grows wild, closing in around the
much-used path and hugging the edge of the building's exterior.  Lanterns
hang from the edge of the monastery's sloped roof, providing meager light
after dark.  The air here is clear and wild, having only a touch of the
acrid fertilizer that is used in the nearby garden.  The dirt path leads to
the east, while two stone steps lead up to the doorway into the Qali forum.

The Western Vestibule
  On the west side of the sanctuary's druidic enclosure is a small
vestibule, which serves as a gateway to this side of the monastery.  Various
hooks for coats and cloaks line the open wall space, taking the place of any
meaningful decoration.  The room itself is built from Nendorin timber, with

rest.  On clear days, light filters through four uneven glass skylights;

scents of the sanctuary drift into the room, mixed with the pleasant aroma
of cooking.  The communal dining hall lies to the west, while the Qali forum
is to the north.  A small hallway leads south.

A Well-Trod Path
  This well-trod path is covered by the canopy of Nendor, crowding out much
of its natural light.  A cobble or two is worked into the hard earth, as if
the path was once fully paved; however, either by removal or wear, many of
them are no longer present.  The forest itself looms overhead, thick trees
and tangled underbrush ensure that travelers tread more or less the same
path every trip.  A few standing lamp posts provide meager light at night,
their metalwork and treated wood showing many decades of wear.  The air here
is clear and wild, drawn through the branches and shrubbery from within the
forest itself.  The path continues to the west, while the cobbles grow more
common as the trees break off to the east.  

[Exits: east west]

A Path Across the Lawn
  Outside the monastery's communal dining hall is a small lawn of thick
grass.  Unlike the yard behind the local ward, the wildlife here is far less
tame.  Nendorin oaks loom to the south, and underbrush crowds out easy
passage.  A cobbled path cuts through the area, its stones old and smooth,
lined at regular intervals with wooden lamp posts.  The edge of the
monastery's sloped roof bears hanging lanterns, providing ample light for a
night time trek.  The air here is clear and wild, drawn through the branches
and underbrush from within the forest itself.  The cobbled path leads to the
north, while the trees open to the west, where the stones give way to packed
dirt.

<485hp 249m 213mv> 
A Communal Dining Hall
  The largest and most active area of the monastery's western side is the
dining room.  It serves all of the monks and devoted who live on the complex
grounds, as well as visitors from Eril, Var Bandor, and beyond.  The ceiling
is high and supported by beams of Nendorin oak; the wooden walls are
unpainted, instead favoring a pleasant varnish.  Long communal tables and
benches line the area, encouraging community between those who eat here. 
The air smells of food at almost all hours, either from what is being
prepared, or was for the last meal.  A study wooden door leads to the
monastery's small western lawn, while the dining area continues to the east
and south.

The Western Vestibule
  On the west side of the sanctuary's druidic enclosure is a small
vestibule, which serves as a gateway to this side of the monastery.  Various
hooks for coats and cloaks line the open wall space, taking the place of any
meaningful decoration.  The room itself is built from Nendorin timber, with
heavy wooden beams supporting the ceiling and treated planks composing the
rest.  On clear days, light filters through four uneven glass skylights;
otherwise, it is lit by a central hanging bronze lantern.  The sweet, exotic
scents of the sanctuary drift into the room, mixed with the pleasant aroma
of cooking.  The communal dining hall lies to the west, while the Qali forum
is to the north.  A small hallway leads south.

<494hp 256m 229mv> An Enclosed Sanctuary
  A step outside the western vestibule is the monastery's miraculous
sanctuary.  Here, the wondrous variety of the Qali clan's druidic mastery is
more than apparent; tall pines, spidery lowland trees, elms, beeches, and
wide goldenrain leaves are all visible.  The earth underfoot is dark and
fertile, partially concealed by a cover of purple irises.  Stones bearing
ancient druidic markings are dug into the soil here and there, bending the
local climate to what suits the diverse array of flora.  The air is a wash
of scents, from stone, to moss, to salt, to swamp mist, to blooming flowers.
A meandering cobbled path leads through the wildlife, directing visitors
east, while smaller bare stretches lead north and south.

<494hp 256m 228mv> 
The Sanctuary's Heart
  At the heart of the monastery is a bounteous grove, cultivated by both
druidic ritual and centuries of meticulous tending.  The plot is roughly
circular, the earth richer and darker than one would expect for the region. 
From it grow a thick cover of ever-blooming white lilies, split only by a
meandering cobbled footpath.  In the grove's center, a spectacular living
sculpture depicts a young caladaran girl, shaped entirely from carefully
bent saplings.  The air is alive with fragrance, capturing some essential,
foreign spirit in its headiness.  The sanctuary continues in all directions,
halting only when it reaches the walls of its stone enclosure.

A Copse of Elm and Beech
  In the southwest portion of the sanctuary blossoms a fragment of the
rugged forest of Morn.  Mossy boulders brought from its rockfalls rise from
the dark Nendorin soil, interspersed with mighty elms and regal grey
beeches.  Despite being so far from their natural climate, they grow with
wild tenacity, rising high above the stone walls which close them in.  A
druidic circle surrounds much of where they grow, each smooth stone marked
with runic carvings.  The air here has a cool bite to it, much more akin to
the mountain valleys at the foot of the Brintors.  The enclosed sanctuary
continues to the north and to the east.

<494hp 256m 225mv> 
l 2.
A lean, brown-skinned ethron woman, Eliqali both adds new flora to the
monastic sanctuary, and maintains what already grows there.  With vivid
green eyes and wild, olive hair, she is both talented and striking; her
mastery of druidic runestones is rivaled only by Avendar's most famous
hierophants.  A daughter of clan Qali, she was born and raised on monastery
grounds, training with the elder matrons as a teenager and traveling as a
young adult.  After returning home, she vowed to the All-Mother that she
would spend her life here, making certain that the wondrous legacy of her
ancestors would endure.  
Eliqali is in excellent condition.

A Rise of Mountain Pines
  In the southeast corner of the sanctuary is a rise of mountain pines,
brought from the ancient forests surrounding Castle Nathli.  Large Brintoran
rocks have been arranged between them, the occasional root reaching over it
to plunge into the earth.  The soil is lighter than elsewhere in the
sanctuary, and mixed with small, jagged rocks; pine needles mask the ground
in a blanket of light browns.  A druidic monolith stands between two of the
trees, its face scored with two ancient runes.  The air here feels thin,
making it subtly more difficult for one to catch their breath, and as dry as
in the pines' native clime.  The enclosed sanctuary continues to the north
and west.

A Shadowy Twist of Wetland
  In the northeast portion of the sanctuary is an unnatural sight: a muddy
stretch of Sythtys wetland and connected pond.  The soil is thick, brown,
and slick, quite unlike the dark earth characteristic of the monastery
grounds.  A light mist clings to the ground, ferns and other small, stubborn
plants peeking out from its wispy depths.  Twisted-bark trees spider upward,
canopying the area, and clutching as much at the enclosure's stone walls as
sinking into the mud below.  A weak swamp stench drifts on the air, which
hangs heavy over this shard of wetland; no doubt induced by the glowing
druidic markers at the mire's edges.  The enclosed sanctuary continues to
the west and south.

The Monastery Garden
  To the north of the sanctuary's enclosure is the local garden, which
provides a small portion of the monks' food.  Vegetables are planted in
orderly rows, the dark earth fertile enough for an impressive yield relative
to their size.  The footprints of residents mark out paths between the rows,

other sections of the monastery exterior, there are no lanterns along the
roof's edge.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the heady
aroma of tilled earth.  To the east, the garden continues, the stone wall of
the sanctuary opening up to the south.

<502hp 263m 233mv> 
A Small Dirt Path
  Behind the monastery is a dirt path leading from the Qali forum to the
monastery's well.  A shortcut for thirsty petitioners, the earth is packed
hard from many generations of footsteps.  Like the rest of the untended
space behind the complex, lush grass grows wild, closing in around the
much-used path and hugging the edge of the building's exterior.  Lanterns
hang from the edge of the monastery's sloped roof, providing meager light
after dark.  The air here is clear and wild, having only a touch of the
acrid fertilizer that is used in the nearby garden.  The dirt path leads to
the east, while two stone steps lead up to the doorway into the Qali forum.

At the Stone Well
  In the northwest corner of the local garden, the orderly rows slow to a
halt.  The earth here is covered by lush, pleasant grass, much of it padded
down from the passage of feet.  The natural spring which serves the
monastery is found here; the source of local water for monks and visitors. 
A single, bronze lantern hangs over the well, providing just enough light to
locate it in the dark.  The air carries the mild sting of fertilizer and the
heady aroma of tilled earth, as well as the smell of water on stone.  A dirt
path leads westward behind the monastery, while the garden proper waits to
the east and south.  

[Exits: east south west]
     A stone well supplies the monastery's water.

<502hp 263m 231mv> 
The Monastery Garden
  The local garden sprawls pleasantly behind the monastery's central
enclosure.  Vegetables are planted in orderly rows, the dark earth fertile
enough for an impressive yield relative to their size.  The footprints of
residents mark out paths between the rows, and a small surrounding fence
keeps forest denizens mostly at bay.  Unlike other sections of the monastery
exterior, there are no lanterns along the roof's edge.  The air carries the
mild sting of fertilizer and the heady aroma of tilled earth.  The
monastery's communal fountain lies to the west, while the garden continues
to the south.  To the east is the ward's grassy yard.  

[Exits: east south west]
     A cabbage patch grows within the garden.
     A plot for growing carrots is set into the earth.

A Lush Green Yard
  Outside of the monastery ward, a grassy strip has been cleared for
patients to enjoy.  The grass is long and lush, spotted with the occasional
dandelions, and small shrubs hunch beneath the monastery's large windows. 
Here, the scents of the forest follow the wind through its branches at the
yard's edges, Nendor's wild encroachment becomes impassable.  A small line
of hanging lanterns hang from the edge of the ward's sloped roof, keeping
the yard lit at night.  The verdant expanse continues to the east, while the
local monastic garden opens up to the west.

A Soothing Ward
  The monastery ward is a simple affair, built out of Nendorin timber and
painted in a soothing pink.  Windows, large and clean, are the most
prominent feature of its north side, giving patients important exposure to
the monastery exterior.  The floor is made of worn hardwood, scuffed from
decades of use, but clear of any noticeable stains.  A line of cots follows
the southern wall, giving the suffering a place to sleep during their stay. 
The air is fresh, a cross-breeze between its two doors keeping it from
becoming too hot in the summer.  The ward continues to the west, while a
door to the yard waits to the north.

l 4.
An older man with salt and pepper hair, Lirannen oversees the local ward
and tends the injured.  Trained in both Water and Earth, he grew into one of
the most prominent archmages of Salyra; yet, he abandoned his high-profile
position in Earendamian politics because of an unusual dream.  He claims
that in it, Alajial soothed his bitter heart.  Unwilling to return to his
old life, he gave away what he owned and made the trek to Nendor.  The
masters accepted him, and he serves as both a healer, and a trusted liaison
between the monastery and the Var Bandor Merchant Council.  
Lirannen is in excellent condition.

The Eastern Vestibule
  On the east side of the sanctuary's druidic enclosure is the gateway to
this side of the monastery.  This vestibule serves as a small resting area,
with low wooden benches set against the walls for monks or petitioners.  The
structure itself is built entirely from Nendorin timber, with heavy wooden
beams supporting the ceiling and treated planks forming its walls.  On clear
days, light filters into the room through four uneven glass skylights;
otherwise, it is lit by a central hanging bronze lantern.  The sweet, heady
scents of the sanctuary drift into the room, tempered by the faint odor of
smoke and oil.  To the north is the local ward; to the south, sleeping
quarters; and to the east, an ascetic common area.  

[Exits: north east south west]

The Entrance to Lijenin Hall
  The central eastern section of the monastery is the oldest still
standing, housing its local psionicists.  While not the original
construction, it has been faithfully tended, repaired, and rebuilt by the
Lijenin Order for centuries.  Massive wooden supports in the walls and
overhead support the east side's sloped roof, and its wooden walls are
painted a mild off-white.  Bronze lanterns are mounted on each side of the
hall to light the interior with burning oil.  Because of the series of open
doorways, fresh air mingles its way into the hall, relieving it of its
closeness.  To the east, the section continues, while to the west is the
eastern vestibule.  

[Exits: east west]
A human monk stands before the threshold of the hall interior.

The Resting Quarters
  The resting quarters for the monastery are quite spartan indeed.  Most
noticeably, there are no cots; instead, a series of thin bedrolls have been
rolled out on the wooden floor, close together, and no apparent other
furniture.  The walls are beige, and comforting in the way only something
well-worn and lived-in can be.  There are no lamps, above or mounted to the
walls; the room's light comes from a series of blurry windows built into the
southern wall.  While still relative fresh, the air here carries with it
some of the animal closeness one would expect of a living space.  The
eastern vestibule waits to the north, while the resting quarters continue to
the east.

<511hp 270m 230mv> 
An Enclosed Sanctuary
  A step outside the eastern vestibule is the monastery's miraculous
sanctuary.  Here, the wondrous variety of the Qali clan's druidic mastery is
more than apparent; tall pines, spidery lowland trees, elms, beeches, and
wide goldenrain leaves are all visible.  The earth underfoot is dark and
fertile, partially concealed by a smattering of rare black orchids.  Stones
bearing ancient druidic markings are dug into the soil here and there,
bending the local climate to what suits the diverse array of flora.  The air
is a wash of scents, from stone, to moss, to salt, to swamp mist, to
blooming flowers.  A meandering cobbled path leads through the wildlife,
directing visitors west, while smaller bare stretches lead north and south. 

[Exits: north east south west]

<511hp 270m 229mv> 
w
The Sanctuary's Heart
  At the heart of the monastery is a bounteous grove, cultivated by both
druidic ritual and centuries of meticulous tending.  The plot is roughly
circular, the earth richer and darker than one would expect for the region. 
From it grow a thick cover of ever-blooming white lilies, split only by a
meandering cobbled footpath.  In the grove's center, a spectacular living
sculpture depicts a young caladaran girl, shaped entirely from carefully
bent saplings.  The air is alive with fragrance, capturing some essential,
foreign spirit in its headiness.  The sanctuary continues in all directions,
halting only when it reaches the walls of its stone enclosure.  

[Exits: north east south west]

At the Wooden Gates
  Twelve feet tall and worked from Nendorin oak, the complex's entrance
maintains a careful balance between secure and welcoming.  The stone of the
monastery's central enclosure rises a few feet above the top of the
woodwork, its interior wildlife pushing at is boundaries.  From here, the
high, sloped roof rises prominently, revealing the monastery's split
eastern-western design.  The forest air is sweet, the faint breath of lilies
in its rich undertone.  A dirt path leads south back toward the forest,
while the monastery's famous sanctuary lies to the north.

Before Chanisal Monastery
  The footpath comes to an end here, just before the wooden gates of the
monastery.  The buildings are tall, but below the mighty Nendorin canopy;
the proper size and sprawl of the complex is not apparent further west.  The
trees give way to long, thick grasses which encroach on the smooth cobbles
of the path and peek between some of its stones.  Wooden posts sporting
bronze enclosures are sparse, but provide enough light to make the way
visible even at night.  The air is fragrant and wild, the scents of the
forest and its creatures drifting upon it.  To the north is the entrance to
the monastery complex, while the uneven path continues west.

A Cleared Path
  This dirt path through the forest of Nendor segues into cobblestones, and
the carefully cleared underbrush is overtaken by patches of trees and high
grass.  Tiny, stubborn weeds stick up between some of the stones, but it
does little to diminish the welcome wear of the road underfoot.  Dense
underbrush obstructs some of the view, but even from here, a large structure
is apparent to the north through the tangle.  A few wooden lamp posts
provide light for the approach, beginning roughly where the cobbles do.  The
sweet scent of the forest rides on the breeze, as pleasant as one could
hope.  The worn road continues to the south, while the light posts lead east
to a clearing.  

[Exits: east south]

<541hp 284m 240mv> By the Ivy-Covered Gate Posts
  The old carriageway continues south, passing between a pair of old,
stone gateposts.  The posts are of mortared bluestone blocks, roughly hewn,
and built into pinnacles some six feet high.  The gates themselves have long
since vanished, and all that remains of them are the heavy iron hinges,
bolted to the stone.  Thick ivy covers the gateposts, and the surrounding
shrubs almost completely obscure their presence.  To the south the path
continues through the trees, while on the northern side of the posts it
turns sharply west.

<541hp 284m 239mv> 
A Rutted Carriageway
  A rutted carriageway winds north and south here, between the trees of
Nendor forest.  Once cobbled with flat, white stones, the path is now badly
overgrown.  The stones are now pushed askew by grasses and saplings, or lie
buried in the mud which crowds in from the edges.  The leafy boughs of the
tall, slender trees hang over the carriage-way, forming a light tunnel.  To
the north the path passes some old gate posts, while to the south the trees
give way, revealing an ivy-covered manor house.  

[Exits: north south]

<541hp 284m 238mv> 
s
By the Doors of an Old Mansion
  Looming above you to the south is an old, stone mansion.  The building is
two stories high, with a tall bluestone tower set into the northwestern
corner. Most of this front face of the mansion is covered with thick ivy,
blending the building with the surrounding forest.  Only a few patches of
lichen-ridden stone look out from the ivy, and shattered windows high
overhead peer blankly at the tree-tops.  The carriageway, which leads north
into the forest, turns east here, and disappears around the side of the
mansion. A set of heavy oak doors hang loose on their hinges to the south.

The Entrance Hall
  Once splendidly appointed, this large entrance chamber is now in a state
of ruin and decay.  Wooden beams from the high, exposed roof hang
precariously from their sockets, now forming perches for the birds of the
forest, which come and go through the broken stained-glass windows. 
Girdling the southern half of the room is a wide balcony -- now unreachable,
as its wooden staircase has long since collapsed, blocking a door in the
eastern wall.  Several clocks, of different shapes and sizes, hang from the
plaster walls about the chamber, or lie toppled in the debris of the floor. 

Double doors are set in both the north and south walls, while in the western
wall the door has fallen from its hinges, and a faint, tinkling music comes
from the room beyond.

The Balcony Over the Entrance Hall
  A wide balcony overlooks the ruins of the entrance hall, some twenty feet
below. Beyond the loose ceiling beams, some of which hang down almost to
this level, large, arched windows gape out at the surrounding forest, their
once-intricate stained-glass faces now lying shattered on the ground below. 
The floor of the balcony itself is nearly rotted through in many places, and
creaks disturbingly with every step.  

The balcony extends half way around the southern part of the chamber, ending
to the east in a gaping hole, where the wooden staircase has collapsed, and
to the west where a door is set into the wall, facing a broken ballustrade. 
Another door is set in the center of the southern wall.

A Dusty Sitting Room
  The curving wall of the tower cuts through this room to the northwest,
giving it an odd, almost-triangular shape.  It is efficiently furnished as a
comfortable sitting room, with a couple of divans and a single armchair
arranged about the walls, all covered in dusty white sheets.  Against the
narrow segment of the northern wall, in the nook formed between the tower
and the eastern wall, is set a beautiful, gilded harpsichord.  A tinkling
music streams from the instrument, and its keys depress and rise again, as
though at the hands of an invisible musician.  

An open doorway leads to a large chamber to the east, and a closed doorway
to the south.

A Mouldering Dining Room
  A long dining room extends to the north and south, and is sparsely
furnished, with only an ornately-carved dining table and its dozen chairs

By a Burbling Fountain
  This wide patio area is paved with granite flagstones, which form a
circular pattern about a large, ornate fountain.  The fountain seems to be
fed by a natural spring, because it gushes steadily with cool, clear water. 
The bowl of the fountain is cracked, and the whole structure stands
lopsided, spilling the flow southward across the patio.  Surrounding the
fountain are a few stone benches, and looming over the whole area are the
great stone arches which support the high eastern wall.  

To the north, a collapsed wall reveals a burnt-out kitchen, and to south a
pebbly path disappears into marshy ground.  The dense forest presses in to
the west.

Upon Marshy Ground
  The puddles and streams of this miniature swamp are fed from the north,
where a spring-fed fountain gushes into a trickling stream.  The waters
spread out to cover much of the ground here, creating a muddy area, studded
with deep, murky puddles.  Only a few spindley gorse bushes grow from the
sodden ground, their small, yellow flowers doing little to liven the area. 

The puddles are fed from a broken fountain to the north, which burbles
between the western forest and the looming mansion to the northeast.  To the
south a large willow grows, and a pebbly path climbs out of the marsh to
wind eastward.

Beneath the Willow Tree
  A large willow tree leans over the sodden ground, sprinkling the puddles
and rivulets with slender green leaves.  The canopy formed by the long,
sinuous branches of the willow comes almost to the ground, creating a
shielded, almost peaceful space.  Several birds hop about the marshy ground,
hunting for food in the mud.  The marsh continues to the north, while to the
west the waters gather themselves, and plunge into the forest as a burbling
stream.  To the east a pile of felled timber blocks the way, and to the
south the thick forest presses in.

A Widening Stream
  The little stream widens here, over a flat area of pebbly ground, several

A Silent Pond
  A large pond spreads between the forested banks, fed by a little stream
to the east.  A thick network of tree roots project from the steep banks,
plunging into the water.  The trees grow densely, and overhang the pond,
blocking almost all view of the sky.  The water is still for the most part,
and glorious water lilies float on its murky surface, each of their circular
green leaves holding a fiery, crimson flower.  Amidst this burning flotilla,
peculiar currents occasionally stir the water, sending the lillies bobbing
and swaying.  

The pond continues to the south.  

[Exits: east south down]

A Silent Pond
  The still waters of this murky pond spread beneath the overhanging boughs
of the forest.  The banks here are thick with slender reeds, which grow down
into the muddy shallows of the pond.  Their long stalks sway gently in the
faint breezes from the forest, filling the air with a susurrant rattle. 
Occasionally a swirling current will come from the deeper parts of the pond,
as though something were moving in its depths.  

The pond continues to the north, while to the east the low, reed-clad bank
of the pond may be climbed.

Beneath the Willow Tree

and rivulets with slender green leaves.  The canopy formed by the long,
sinuous branches of the willow comes almost to the ground, creating a
shielded, almost peaceful space.  Several birds hop about the marshy ground,

stream.  To the east a pile of felled timber blocks the way, and to the
south the thick forest presses in.

Upon Marshy Ground
  The puddles and streams of this miniature swamp are fed from the north,
where a spring-fed fountain gushes into a trickling stream.  The waters
spread out to cover much of the ground here, creating a muddy area, studded
with deep, murky puddles.  Only a few spindley gorse bushes grow from the
sodden ground, their small, yellow flowers doing little to liven the area. 

The puddles are fed from a broken fountain to the north, which burbles
between the western forest and the looming mansion to the northeast.  To the
south a large willow grows, and a pebbly path climbs out of the marsh to
wind eastward.

Beneath the Bandits' Shelter
  A few sheets of canvas form the sloping roof of this crude shelter, held
in place by a row of birch trees to the north, and a thick growth of
white-flowered privet to the south.  The privet also grows to the west,
although more thinly, and a wall of blackberries blocks the eastern exit. 
The floor of the shelter is littered with blankets, filthy clothing, and
shabby personal belongings of little worth - clearly the refuge of an
unsavoury gang.

A Tunnel Beneath the Privet Bushes
  A narrow tunnel has been hacked through the middle of this growth of
privet shrubs, leading away south.  A thin veil of branches seems to have
been left to the east, to obscure the location of the tunnel.  The
intertwining branches of the privet bushes form a thick wall about the
tunnel, studded with dark leaves and small, delicate-looking white flowers. 
The fragrance of the flowers is heady and sweet, and washes thickly over you
as you pass beneath the thicket.

corner of the room.  Each appears to be a moving part from a variety of

Inside the Southern Gatehouse
  The southern gatehouse of Var Bandor is an elaborate affair,
well-maintained and proper.  A close watch is kept on the kind of traveler
allowed to enter the finest districts of the city, and a roster of those
banned from the area is kept nearby.  The immense granite walls rise to
either side of the gates, and to the south, the outskirts of Var Bandor run
into a thickly wooded area.  North, Ilrin Street leads into the heart of the
city.

Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

<412hp 274m 265mv> The Journey's End
  The Journey's End is a nice inn, though with closer examination you note
cobwebs that would not be present if this inn were in a more reputable part
of town.  A small bar stands in one corner, but most of the hard core
drinkers will go to one of the other numerous pubs along the road.  The
innkeeper stands behind the bar, accepting coin for his rooms upstairs, and
for food and drink alike.  The inn continues to the south, with more tables
for customers to sit down and relax, and there is a small door behind the
bar leading to the innkeeper's personal room.  North is the door back to the
bustle of Dantaron Road.  

[Exits: north (east) south]
The innkeeper bustles around the room, a warm welcoming smile on his round face.
A woman sits here, enjoying the peace of the inn.
A patron of the inn sits here, enjoying a fine meal.
A young boy sits here, spinning a brightly coloured top.

<412hp 274m 264mv> 
n
Dantaron Street
  Dantaron Street bisects the west half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the western gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the north, a large temple constructed of fine white marble
rises over the street.  To the south is a traveller's inn.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<412hp 274m 262mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

n
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the south is the central square of
Var Bandor.

Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends

known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield

boarded over, and the other is made of bubbled, foggy glass.  An imitation
Harrudim rug covers most of the uneven floor, and a roughly made counter is
toward the east side of the room.  Instruments are mounted on the walls
along with dim lights, providing examples of the shop's wares.  A wooden
doorway leads west.

Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the west, Iron Street leads into
the industrial section of Var Bandor, and to the east, Raddin street winds
through some run-down buildings.

<330hp 275m 258mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<320hp 305m 247mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A bedraggled orange tabby cat with a tattered ear and a mournful expression is here.

An armed enforcer of Var Bandor stands here.

<320hp 305m 246mv> 
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the south is the central square of
Var Bandor.

Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned

<404hp 320m 244mv> A Dingy Office
  This one-room office is small and hopelessly seedy.  Dirty grey plaster
is cracked and bubbled in many places, stains and discolorations covering
the surface.  The roofbeams sag wearily, and the creaky floor is bowed and
warped.  Equally flimsy chairs are lined against the eastern wall.  The room
smells of damp and mold, and apparently hasn't been cleaned in years.  A
high desk, built to eliminate the need for a stool, sits opposite the
chairs.  An incredibly grimy window is made of dozens of thick, blurry panes
of cheap glass.  The window admits slightly less light than the open doorway
beside it which leads north out of the room.  

[Exits: north]
A burly ethron mercenary paces about his office.

<413hp 328m 253mv> 
A Run-Down Weaponry
  This small store is particularly cramped and showing of age.  The ceiling
is cracked across the center, and the paint and plaster look aged and in
some need of repair.  Despite this, examples of the shop's unusual wares
hang along the walls on display, made primarily of wood and iron.  Weapons
of all types are arrayed throughout the shop, leaning or mounted.  The floor
is worn and rickety, and the shop's main counter is battered and worn from
years of sales.  Smaller work can be done in a small kiln in the back room,
but that seems more for repairs or modifications than to create the massive
wares the shop sells.  Raddin Street lies through the door to the north.  

[Exits: north]
A grizzled, scarred alatharya works within the shop.

<413hp 328m 251mv> 
The Saurian Armory
  This armory is unusually hot, presumably both because of the kiln against
the shop's north wall, and because of the tastes of its clientele.  An anvil
sits prominently near it, with a variety of tools stewn haphazardly about
the room.  Examples of the shop's unique wares hang from the walls, the
mounted skull-masks and intricately carved metal plates leering from the
aging walls.  Various hide and bone fetishes serve as the room's only other
apparent decorations, giving the entire affair a far more barbarous feel. 
The floor is marked by small scorches, where still-hot metal made a lasting
impression upon it.  To the south is Raddin Street, and the far cooler air
of the city.

  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the west, Iron Street leads into
the industrial section of Var Bandor, and to the east, Raddin street winds
through some run-down buildings.

s
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.

<427hp 328m 247mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned
with a sword calls attention to the weapon shop to the south.  Raddin street
continues to the east, while the main drag of Sadrent road opens to the
west.  

[Exits: north east south west]

Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends

known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  Raddin Street

<427hp 328m 244mv> 
The Wench's Lute
  This shop lies just off of the east end of Raddin Street, and is exactly
as dingy as one might expect for the surroundings.  One of the windows is
boarded over, and the other is made of bubbled, foggy glass.  An imitation
Harrudim rug covers most of the uneven floor, and a roughly made counter is
toward the east side of the room.  Instruments are mounted on the walls
along with dim lights, providing examples of the shop's wares.  A wooden
doorway leads west.  

[Exits: west]
An unsavory human woman tends the counter.

The Tipsy Swordmaster
  The Tipsy Swordmaster is a tavern frequented by the less wealthy
mercenary classes of Var Bandor.  Filled with thick smoke from tobacco
pipes, the large common room of the tavern is filled with the loud sounds of
drinking warriors.  Some scattered tables are filled with boisterous

<466hp 228m 252mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  Raddin Street
deadends at a stone wall to the east, and returns to the west.  North is a
run-down flophouse, and a large tavern to the south is decorated with a sign
proclaiming it to be the Tipsy Swordmaster.  

[Exits: (north) east south west]
A battered and scarred gladiator guards the entrance to the tavern.

Raddin Street

its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned

<466hp 228m 249mv> 
w
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the west, Iron Street leads into
the industrial section of Var Bandor, and to the east, Raddin street winds
through some run-down buildings.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<466hp 228m 245mv> 
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]
